Dian. 195); ἐξ ὀχέων . . ἆλτο χαμᾶζε Il. 6.103; ἆλτο κατʼ Οὐλύμπου 18.616:— ἅλλεσθαι ἐπί τινι leap upon or against, 21.174, Od. 22.80; ἐπὶ στίχας Il. 20.353: c. inf., ἆλτο θέειν, πέτεσθαι, h.Cer. 389, Ap. 448: abs., of horse, X. Eq. 8.4.
leap over, βόθρον Ael. NA 6.6; τάφρον Opp. C. 1.83.
ἆλτο ὀϊστός Il. 4.125; of sound, ἀπὸ λείων ἠχὼ ἁλλομένη Pl. Phdr. 255c; of parts of body, twitch, quiver, throb, ἅλλεται ὀφθαλμός Theoc. 3.37, cf. Arist. HA 604a27, PRyl. 1.28.
disguise oneself, Ps.-Callisth. 1.3; change oneʼs shape, Sm. Ez. 31.15.
of strange shape, τέρατα, σώματα Hp. Morb. 4.93.

definition: ἀλλόμος τυφλός, Hsch.; i. e. ἀλαό[λαο]ς.

children.definition: subjection to external influences, D.S. 26.1.
subject to external influence, hence in Gramm. of Pronouns, non-reflexive, A.D. Pron. 44.17, Synt. 175.13, EM 496.45.
Adv. -θῶς of Verbs, transitively, Eust. 920.27.

definition: ἀλλοπίας, Ep. ἀλλοπ-ίης, ὁ, a fish, Numen. ap. Ath. 7.326a.

children.definition: producing otherness, Procl. in Prm. p.569 S.
Leg.Gort. 6.47: hence ἀλλο-πολιᾶται, οἱ, GDI 4954 (Cret.).

definition: ἀλλοπρόσαλλος, ὁ, i.e. ἄλλοτε πρὸς ἄλλον,

children.definition: leaning first to one side, then to the other, fickle, epith. of Ares, Il. 5.831, 889, cf. Eun. VS p.496 B.; πλοῦτος AP 15.12, cf. 1.34 ( Agath.); τὸ ἀ. respect of persons, Corp. Herm.18.14.
transferred, ἀ. ἀρωγή, coupled with ἑτεραλκέα νίκην, Tryph. 565; deceitful, Nonn. D. 46.4, al.; changeful, successive, of waves, etc. (cf. ἀλλεπάλληλος), ib. 3.24, al., cf. Man. 5.68.

definition: ἄλλος, η, ο, Cypr. αἶλος Inscr.Cypr. 135 H. ( Idalion): (from ἀλyος, cf. Lat. alius):—

children.definition: another, i.e. one besides what has been mentioned, either Adj. or Pron.: when Adj., its Subst. is either in the same case, or in gen., Ζεῦ ἄλλοι τε θεοί Il. 6.476; θεῶν ἄ. 16.446:— ἄ. μέν . . ἄ. δέ . . one . . another . . , more rarely the one . . the other . . (of two persons, etc.), Il. 22.493, etc.; τὰ μέν . . ἄλλα δέ . . Il. 6.147, and Att.; ἕτερον μέν . . ἄλλον δέ . . Il. 9.313; ἄλλο μέν . . ἑτέρου δέ . . Hdt. 1.32; θάτερον . . τὸ δʼ ἄλλο E. IT 962.

children.label: II
children.definition: τις, any other, οὐδέ τις ἄ. ἔγνω ἀλλʼ ἄρα Κασσάνδρη Il. 24.697; ἄ. τις Hdt. 3.85; οὐδεὶς ἄ. no other, ibid.; ἄλλα πολλά Il. 9.639; πολλὰ καὶ ἄλλα Th. 3.56; for εἴ τις ἄλλος Id. 6.32, etc., and εἴ τις καὶ ἄ. X. An. 1.4.15, etc., v. εἰ.

data.quote: οὐδέ τις ἄ. ἔγνω ἀλλʼ ἄρα Κασσάνδρη

children.definition: ἄ. ἄλλα λέγει one man says one thing, one another, X. An. 2.1.15; ἄ. ἄλλωʼ ἔλεγεν Pl. Smp. 220c; ἄ. ἄλλῃ ἐτράπετο X. An. 4.8.19; v. ἄλλοθεν, ἄλλοσε, ἄλλοτε; also with Verb in pl., παραλαμβάνων ἄ. ἄλλον ἐπʼ ἄλλου, τὸν δʼ ἐπʼ ἄλλου χρείᾳ . . ἐθέμεθα πόλιν ὄνομα Pl. R. 369c, cf. X. Cyr. 2.1.4, etc.: pl., ἄλλοι when the several parties are pl., λείπουσι τὸν λόφον . . ἄλλοι ἄλλοθεν X. An. 1.10.13.

data.quote: παραλαμβάνων ἄ. ἄλλον ἐπʼ ἄλλου, τὸν δʼ ἐπʼ ἄλλου χρείᾳ . . ἐθέμεθα πόλιν ὄνομα

children.definition: ἄ. καὶ ἄ., one and then another, one or two, X. An. 1.5.12; ἄλλο καὶ ἄλλο one thing after another, Id. Cyr. 4.1.15; πρὸς ἄλλῳ καὶ ἄλλῳ σημείῳ to different points, Euc. 1.7.
ἄ. ἄ. τρόπος quite another sort, E. Ph. 132.
οὐδʼ ἄ. for οὐδέτερος, Theoc. 6.45.

ὁ ἄλλος, the rest, all besides; in pl., οἱ ἄλλοι ( Ion. contr. ὧλλοι) all the others, the rest, freq. from Hom. downwards ( ἄλλοι in same signf., Il. 2.1); τὰ ἄλλα, contr. τἆλλα, all else, τἆλλα πλὴν ὁ χρυσός Scol. 1 (Pytherm.); in Att. freq. as Adv., for the rest, esp. in amendments to decrees, τὰ μὲν ἄλλα καθάπερ ὁ δεῖνα κτλ. IG 1.27a70, etc.: of Time, = τὸν ἄλλον χρόνον, X. HG 3.2.2; ὁ ἄ. χρόνος, = ὁ λοιπὸς χρόνος, of the future, Lys. 14.4 (but also of the past, D. 20.16); τῇ ἄλλῃ ἡμέρᾳ, τῷ ἄλλῳ ἔτει, next day, next year, X. HG 1.1.13, 1.2.1; οἵτε ἄλλοι καί . . all others and especially . . , γυναῖκας ἄλλας τε πολλὰς καὶ δὴ καὶ βασιλέος θυγατέρα Hdt. 1.1, etc.; ἄλλα τε δὴ εἶπε, καί . . Pl. Tht. 142c; (v. ἄλλως I):— τὸ ἄλλο is much less freq. than τὰ ἄλλα.

data.quote: γυναῖκας ἄλλας τε πολλὰς καὶ δὴ καὶ βασιλέος θυγατέρα

children.definition: yet, still, further, τρίτον ἄ. γένος Hes. Op. 143; πέμπτος ποταμὸς ἄ. yet a fifth river, Hdt. 4.54, cf. A. Th. 486, S. Ant. 1295, etc.

as well, besides, ἅμα τῇγε καὶ ἀμφίπολοι κίον ἄλλαι with her their mistress came attendants also, Od. 6.84; μήτηρ ἠδὲ πατὴρ ἠδʼ ἄλλοι πάντες ἑταῖροι 9.367; οὐ γὰρ ἦν χόρτος οὐδὲ ἄ. δένδρον οὐδέν there was no grass nor any tree at all, X. An. 1.5.5; πολιτῶν καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ξένων Pl. Grg. 473d; προσοφλὼν οὐ τὴν ἐπωβελίαν μόνον ἀλλὰ καὶ ἄλλην ὕβριν besides, Aeschin. 1.163:—pleonastic, παρʼ ἀγγέλων ἄλλων ἀκούειν S. OT 7, cf. X. Cyr. 1.6.2; ἰδὼν ἐς πλησίον ἄλλον Il. 4.81; γυναικῶν τῶν ἄλλων μία E. Med. 945; μόνη τῶν ἄλλων ἐπιστημῶν Pl. Chrm. 166e; with Comp., freq. in Hom., οὔτις σεῖο νεώτερος ἄ. Ἀχαιῶν Il. 15.569, cf. 22.106, al.; with Sup., ὀϊζυρώτατος ἄλλων Od. 5.105.

data.quote: μήτηρ ἠδὲ πατὴρ ἠδʼ ἄλλοι πάντες ἑταῖροι

children.label: III
children.definition: of other sort, different, Il. 13.64, 21.22; ἄ. γέγονεν Pl. Phdr. 241a.

ἄλλα τῶν δικαίων other than just, X. Mem. 4.4.25:—followed by ἤ . . , with preceding neg., οὐδὲ ἄλλο . . , οὐδὲν ἄλλο (or ἄλλο οὐδέν) . ., ἤ . . nothing else than . . , Hdt. 1.49, 7.168, Th. 4.14; οὐδὲν ἄλλο γʼ ἤπτήξας A. Pers. 209; ἃ μηδὲν ἄλλο ἢ διανεῖταί τις which one only thinks, Pl. Tht. 195e:—more freq. in questions, τίς ἄλλος ἢ ʼγώ . . ; A. Pr. 440; τί δʼ ἄλλογʼ ἢπόνοι . . ; Id. Th. 852: ellipt., τί ἄλλο (sc. πάσχω ) ἢ ἱπποκένταυρος γίγνομαι; X. Cyr. 4.3.20; τί ἄλλο (sc. ἐποίησαν) ἢ ἐπεβούλευσαν; Th. 3.39:—followed by πλήν, S. Aj. 125, Ar. Ach. 39; by Preps., πρό . . Hdt. 3.85; ἀντί . . A. Pr. 467; παρά . . Pl. Phd. 80b, etc.: with neg., sts. followed by ἀλλά, Il. 18.403, 21.275:—see also ἄλλο τι.
other than what is, untrue, unreal, Od. 4.348.
other than right, wrong, bad, ἄλλου τινος ἡττῆσθαι yield to some unworthy motive, D. 21.218, cf. Plu. Apophth.reg. 2.187d, etc.; cf. ἄλλως.
Sapph. 110.

elsewhither, Od. 23.184; ἄλλος ἄ. A. Pers. 359; ἄ . . . ὄμμα θατέρᾳ δὲ νοῦν ἔχοντα S. Tr. 272; to foreign lands, ἄ. ἐκπέμπειν to export, X. HG 6.1.11; ἄ. οὐδαμόσε to no other place, Pl. Cri. 52b; ἄ. πολλαχόσε to many other places, Id. Mx. 241e; ποῖ ἄ.; to what other place? Id. Phd. 82a; ἄ. ποι to some other place, Id. Tht. 202e: c. gen., ἄ. ποι τῆς Σικελίας to some other part of Sicily, Th. 7.51; ἄ. τοῦ σώματος Pl. Lg. 841a:—by attraction, = ἀλλαχοῦ, ἄλλοσε ὅποι ἂν ἀφίκῃ Id. Cri. 45b.

data.quote: ἄ . . . ὄμμα θατέρᾳ δὲ νοῦν ἔχοντα

definition: ἄλλοτε, Aeol. ἄλλοτα Alc. 47, Dor. ἄλλοκα Theoc. 1.37, Adv.

children.definition: at another time, freq. repeated, ἄ. μέν . . ἄ. δέ . . at one time . . at another . . , Il. 23.368, etc.; also ὁτὲ μέν . . , ἄ. δέ . . Il. 11.65; ἄ. μέν . . , ἄ. δʼ αὖτε Od. 16.209, Hes. Fr. 14; τότʼ ἄλλος, ἄλλοθʼ ἅτερος S. El. 739; ποτὲ μὲν κακόν, ἄ. ἐπʼ ἐσθλὸν ἑρπει Id. Ant. 367; ἄ. μέν . . , τότε δέ X. An. 4.1.17: sts. the former ἄλλοτε is omitted, φοιτῶν ἐναργὴς ταῦρος, ἄ. αἰόλος δράκων S. Tr. 11; κεῖμαι δʼ ἐπʼ ἀκταῖς, ἄ. ἐν πόντου σάλῳ E. Hec. 28; ἄ. μέν . . ἐν πυμάτῳ S. OC 1674:— ἄ. καὶ ἄ. now and then, X. An. 2.4.26: -freq. with ἄλλος, etc., πρὸς ἄλλοτʼ ἄλλον sometimes to this man, sometimes that, A. Pr. 278, etc.; ἄλλως ἄ. Th. 1077.

data.quote: ποτὲ μὲν κακόν, ἄ. ἐπʼ ἐσθλὸν ἑρπει
φοιτῶν ἐναργὴς ταῦρος, ἄ. αἰόλος δράκων
κεῖμαι δʼ ἐπʼ ἀκταῖς, ἄ. ἐν πόντου σάλῳ

children.definition: foreign, γῆ Ezek. Exag. 58.
otherness, Simp. in Ph. 862.13.

anything else, in interrog. sentences, mostly foll. by ἤ, ἤ σοι ἄλλο τι φαίνεται . . ἢ λόγος; Pl. Phdr. 258a, cf. Phd. 64c:—hence freq. (esp. in Pl.) elliptical, implying an affirm. answer, ἄλλο τι ἢ πεινήσουσι; (i.e. ἄλλο τι πείσονται ἢ πεινήσουσι;) will they not be starved? Hdt. 2.14, cf. 1.109; ἄλλο τι ἢ ἠρέμα ἐπανασκεψόμεθα; shall we not calmly reconsider? (i.e. let us do so) Pl. Tht. 154e, cf. Phd. 70c, Men. 82d, Grg. 481c, etc.; ἄλλο τι ἢ καταγελῴης ἄν; Id. Alc. 1.116d:— with other words interposed, σκόπει εἰ ἄλλο τι λέγεις ἢ τόδε Id. Smp. 200d, cf. Phd. 106a, Sph. 228a, etc.:— ἄλλοτιπλήν . . ; Id. Sph. 228a:—but often ἄλλο τι with or without οὖν stands alone, ἄλλο τι οὖν . . ἔλεγες; did not you say? Id. Grg. 495c, cf. 470b, Phd. 79b, Tht. 165e, R. 337c, etc.

data.quote: σκόπει εἰ ἄλλο τι λέγεις ἢ τόδε

children.definition: ἀπόγνοια τοῦ ἄλλο τι ἢ κρατεῖν τῆς γῆς Th. 3.85.

data.quote: ἀπόγνοια τοῦ ἄλλο τι ἢ κρατεῖν τῆς γῆς

children.definition: to be ill-disposed, Plb. 15.22.1: c. gen., towards . . , τοῦ βασιλέως ib. 25.34.
thinking of other things, absent, Cratin. 154.
busybody in other menʼs matters, 1 Ep.Pet. 4.15.
speak irrelevantly, Aristox. Harm. p.32 M., Str. 1.4.1.
unorthodox views, Phld. Acad.Ind. p.67 M.
ever changing in form, epith. of nature, Orph. H. 10.23.
assign things to their wrong place, opp. διανέμειν ἐπὶ τὰ αὑτῶν ἕκαστα, Pl. Tht. 195a.

children.label: II
children.definition: adopt foreign customs, D.C. 52.36.
meddle with other folkʼs business: excite commotions, Plb. 5.41.8; opp. αὐτοπραγέω, Procl. in R. 2.149 K.
meddling with other folkʼs business, Plu. Adul. 2.57d, Procl. in R. 1.216K.
Simp. in Epict. pp. 51,113D.
meddlesomeness, Pl. R. 444b, Procl. in Alc. p.14 C.
meddlesome, AB 81.

definition: ἀλλότριος, Aeol. ἀλλότερρος EM 529.24, α, ον, ( ἄλλος)

children.definition: of or belonging to another, βίοτος, νηῦς, ἄχεα, Od. 1.160, 9.535, Il. 20.298; γυνή another manʼs wife, A. Ag. 448 (lyr.); ἀλλοτρίων χαρίσασθαι to be bountiful of what is anotherʼs, Od. 17.452; γναθμοῖσι γελοίων ἀλλοτρίοισιν with faces unlike their own, of a forced, unnatural laugh, ib. 20.347; ἀ. ὄμμασιν εἷρπον by the help of anotherʼs eyes, S. OC 146 (lyr.); οὐκ ἀ. ἄτην not inflicted by other hands, Id. Ant. 1259; but ἀ. φόνος murder of a stranger (cf. ΙΙ.1), Pl. Euthphr. 4b: prov., ἀ. ἀμᾶν θέρος reap where one has not sown, Ar. Eq. 392, cf. Hes. Th. 599; ἀλλοτριωτάτοις τοῖς σώμασιν χρῆσθαι deal with oneʼs body as if it belonged to another, Th. 1.70; τὰ ἀλλότρια, contr. τἀλλότρια, what belongs to others, not oneʼs own, τἀ. ἀποστερεῖν, δειπνεῖν, X. Ages. 4.1, Theopomp.Com. 34.

children.label: II
children.definition: οἰκεῖος, foreign, strange,

ἀ. φώς stranger, Od. 18.219, cf. Ar. Ra. 481; almost = enemy, Il. 5.214, Od. 16.102; οὐδέ τις ἀλλοτρίων no stranger, Hdt. 3.155; εἴτε ἀ. εἴτε οἰκεῖος ὁ τεθνεώς Pl. Euthphr. 4b; ἀ. τῆς πόλεως Lys. 28.6; οὐδείς ἐστί μοι ἀ., ἂν ᾖ χρηστός Men. 602; ἀλλοτριώτερος τῶν παίδων less near than thy children, Hdt. 3.119; ἀλλοτριώτερος, opp. οἰκειότερος, Arist. EN 1162a3: c. dat., ἀλλότριοι ὑμῖν ὄντες Isoc. 14.51.

data.quote: εἴτε ἀ. εἴτε οἰκεῖος ὁ τεθνεώς
οὐδείς ἐστί μοι ἀ., ἂν ᾖ χρηστός

children.label: b
children.definition: hostile, unfavourably disposed, c. gen., ἀ. Ῥωμαίων Plb. 28.4.4; -ώτατος μοναρχίας D.S. 16.65; ἀλλότρια φρονῶν τοῦ βασιλέως Plb. 36.15.7, cf. OGI 90.19 ( Rosetta).

children.label: c
children.definition: disinclined, πρὸς τὰς κακοπαθείας Plb. 36.15.2.

alien, strange, τροφή Pl. R. 491d ( Comp.), etc.; εἴ τι πρότερον γέγονεν ἀ. estrangement, Decr. ap. D. 18.185; ἡ ἀ. alien country, enemyʼs country, Lys. 2.6, Isoc. 10.50, cf. Hdt. 8.73: c. gen., alien from, ἐπιτηδεύματα δημοκρατίας ἀ. Lys. 31.34; οὐδὲν ἀ. ποιῶν τοῦ τρόπου Decr. ap. D. 18.182.

children.label: b
children.definition: abnormal, Sor. 2.5, Gal. 14.780; ἀ. σάρκες superfluous fat, Pl. R. 556d.

children.label: c
children.definition: foreign to the purpose, λόγοι Arist. EE 1218b23: Comp., Id. EN 1159b24: Sup., Id. Cat. 15b29, cf. Polystr. p.17 W.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv. ἀλλοτρίως, διακεῖσθαι πρὸς ἀλλήλας to be unfavourably disposed towards . . , Lys. 33.1, cf. Isoc. 12.159; ἄ. ἔχειν πρός . . Id. 5.80: Comp. -ιώτερον less favourably, D. 18.9.
strangely, marvellously, Epigr.Gr. 989.2.
in a manner foreign to, c. gen., Pers.Stoic. 1.100. [ -ο̄τρ- only in Men. 557 s. v. l.]
derivativeness, opp. οἰκειότης, Pl. Plt. 261a; estrangement, Arist. Pol. 1311b15; τινὸς πρός τινα Pl. Ep. 318d, cf. Decr. ap. D. 18.165, Plb. 38.12.3.
unattractiveness, of style, Phld. Po. 994.6, 37.

children.label: II
children.definition: qualitative difference, Epicur. Nat. 11.12.
eat anotherʼs bread, Eust. 1404.9.
eating anotherʼs bread, S. Fr. 329, Eust. 1404.13.
to be estranged, ill-disposed, D.S. 17.4.
changing colour, AP 11.7 ( Nic.).
of strange land, J. AJ 3.12.3, 8.7.5.
estrange from: c. gen., deprive, τῶν σωμάτων τὴν πόλιν οὐκ ἀλλοτριοῦντες Th. 3.65; τοὺς ἠλλοτριωκότας ἑαυτοὺς ἀπὸ τῆς λῃτουργίας those who have withdrawn themselves from . . , D. 51.17.

data.quote: τῶν σωμάτων τὴν πόλιν οὐκ ἀλλοτριοῦντες

children.definition: make hostile to another, τὴν χώραν τοῖς πολεμίοις X. Cyr. 6.1.16:— Pass., become estranged, be made enemy, τινί Th. 8.73; πρὸς τὴν αἴρεσιν Vit.Philonid. p.12C.; πρός τι to be prejudiced against thing, D.H. Th. 27; ἀπό τινος disguise oneself from, LXX Ge. 42.7; πρὸς τὰ καίοντα to be inaccessible to cautery, Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.22.4.
to be unnatural, have a strange taste, τροφὴν-ιοῦσαν ἔκπτυε Phld. Lib. p.9 O.
Pass., to be alienated from oneʼs natural condition, Pl. Ti. 64e.
Pass., also of things, to be alienated, fall into other hands, ἀλλοτριοῦται ἡ ἀρχή Hdt. 1.120, cf. D. 18.88.

estrangement, Phld. D. 3 Fr. 1; aversion, πρὸς πόνον Gal. 5.459; τινός from one, App. BC 5.78; τινὸς εἴς τινα 3.13; opp. οἰκείωσις, Porph. Abst. 3.19; τῆς ξυμμαχίας οὐχ ὁμοία ἡ ἀ. Th. 1.35:—Medic., loss of substance, mortification, Aët. 13.3.

data.quote: τῆς ξυμμαχίας οὐχ ὁμοία ἡ ἀ.

children.definition: strange, φαντασίαι Linus ap. Stob. 1.10.5; ᾄσματα Iamb. VP 25.114. Adv. -τρόπως Sch. E. Hec. 299.
differently formed, Man. 4.75.
appearing otherwise, Nonn. D. 14.156, Jo.Gaz. 2.225, etc.
to be delirious, Hp. Prog. 20, al., cf. Gal. 18(2).249, prob. l. in Aret. SA 2.4.—Ionic word, cf. Xenocrit. ap. Erot. Fr. 1, Eust. 1324.10.
slain by others, AB 386, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: φαίνομαι) = ἀλλοφανής, Nic. Th. 148.
without a crest, Il. 10.258, AP 6.163 ( Mel.).
one of another φρατρία, IG 14.759 ( Naples).

think of other things, give no heed, ἀλλʼ ἥμην ἀλλοφρονέων Od. 10.374; of one in a swoon, to be senseless, κὰδ δʼ ἀλλοφρονέοντα . . εἷσαν Il. 23.698; κεῖτʼ ἀλλοφρονέων Theoc. 22.129, cf. Arist. Metaph. 1009b30; ὑπὸ τούτων ἀλλοφρονῆσαι were seized with frenzy by reason of the thunder, etc., Hdt. 5.85; ἀλύει καὶ ἀ. ὑπὸ τῆς ὀδύνης Hp. Morb. 2.16, cf. Mul. 1.41.

data.quote: ἀλύει καὶ ἀ. ὑπὸ τῆς ὀδύνης

children.label: II
children.definition: to be of another mind, have other views, v.l. in Hdt. 7.205.
absence or derangement of mind, Poll. 8.163.
thinking differently, Man. 4.563.
changed in shape, Nonn. D. 4.419, al.
of strange, abnormal shape, ib. 2.148, al.
adopt foreign customs or religions, LXX 4 Ma. 18.5.
foreign matter, Epicur. Ep. 2p.48U.
adoption of foreign customs, LXX 2 Ma. 4.13.

of another tribe, foreign, Hp. Aër. 12; freq. in LXX of Philistines, Jd. 14.1, al.; in Egypt, settled in another nome, BGU 419.2 (iii A. D.); ἐς ἀλλόφυλον . . χθόνα A. Eu. 851; ἄνθρωποι Th. 1.102, Pl. Lg. 629d; ζῷα alien to man, wild, D.S. 3.18, Porph. Abst. 1.10; πόλεμος ἀ. war with foreigners, Plu. Cam. 23; opp. ὁμόφυλος, Epicur. Sent. 39; ἀ. πρός τι Dam. Pr. 308; μᾶζαν ἐπʼ ἀ. alien, not oneʼs own, Eup. 159.12.
confusion of tongues, J. AJ 1.4.3.
speaking a foreign tongue, LXX Ez. 3.6, Hsch. s.v. ἀλλόθροος.
to change colour, Arist. Pr. 880a25, Them. Or. 4.56a, 19.228c.
change of colour, Adam. 2.36.
changed in colour, E. Hipp. 174 (lyr.):—also ἀλλό-χρως, ωτος, ὁ, ἡ, looking strange or foreign, Id. Ph. 138, Andr. 879.

definition: ἄλλυδις, Adv., ( ἄλλος) Ep. for ἄλλοσε,

children.definition: elsewhither, in Hom. only with ἄλλος, ἄ. ἄλλος one hither, another thither, Il. 11.486, Od. 5.71, cf. A.R. 2.980, etc.; τρέπεται χρὼς ἄ. ἄλλῃ his colour changes now one way, now another, Il. 13.279; imitated from Hom. by Eup. 159.11; later by itself, AP 15.24.1 ( Simm.).

definition: ἀλλύεσκε, ἀλλύουσα [ῡ], Ep. for ἀνέλυε, ἀναλύουσα.

children.definition: Hdn.Gr. 1.507, prob. in Alc. 89:—also ἀλλῦς (dub.), AB 1316.
Phanocl. 2.

definition: ἄλλως, Dor. ἀλλῶς, A.D. Adv. 175.13, Adv. of ἄλλος,

children.definition: otherwise, Il. 19.401, etc.: freq. with other Advbs., ἄ. πως in some other way, ἄ. οὐδαμῶς in no other wise, Pl. R. 343b, 526a, etc.; πως ἄ. X. Mem. 2.6.39; ἄ. καὶ ἄ. Hierocl. in CA 23p.468M.

καὶ ἄλλως and besides (cf. ἄλλος II.8), ἀγήνωρ ἐστὶ καὶ ἄλλως Il. 9.699; a woman is described as very tall καὶ ἄ. εὐειδής Hdt. 1.60, etc.; ἀρίστου καὶ ἄ. φρονιμωτάτου Pl. Phd. 118a:—so ἄ. δέ . . Hdt. 6.105, Ar. Av. 1476; ἄλλως τε S. OT 1114, Hdt. 8.142.

children.label: b
children.definition: at all events, any how, εἴ πέρ γε καὶ ἄ. ἐθέλει . . Hdt. 7.16.γʹ; ἄλλως alone, εἰ ἄ. βούλοιτο Id. 8.30; ἐπείπερ ἄλλως . . εἰς Ἄργος κίεις A. Ch. 680.

ἄλλως τε καί . . both otherwise and . . , i.e. especially, above all, A. Eu. 473, Th. 1.70, etc.; strengthd., ἄ. τε πάντως καί . . A. Pr. 636, Eu. 726; freq. followed by ἤν, εἰ, ἐπειδή, especially if . . , Hp. VC 21, Th. 1.81, 2.3; by part., Id. 4.104, 7.80:—without καί, ἄ. τε ἐάν X. Mem. 1.2.59; ἄλλως τε ἐπειδή Isoc. 2.51, Pl. Men. 85e, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: otherwise than something implied, differently, τοῦτʼ οὐκ ἔστιν ἄ. εἶπαι to deny it, Hdt. 6.124; οὐκ ἄ. λέγω I say no otherwise, i.e. I say so, E. Hec. 302: hence,
far otherwise, i.e. better, οὐδέ κεν ἄλλως οὐδὲ θεὸς τεύξειε Od. 8.176, cf. Il. 14.53.

data.quote: οὐδέ κεν ἄλλως οὐδὲ θεὸς τεύξειε

children.definition: otherwise than should be, at random, without aim or purpose, Od. 14.124, Hdt. 3.16, 4.77, etc.:— in vain, Il. 23.144; freq. in Trag. and Com., ἀλλʼ ἄ. πονεῖ S. OT 1151, cf. 333, E. Med. 1030, Ar. Eq. 11; with Subst., εἴδωλον ἄ. mere image, S. Ph. 947; ἀριθμὸν ἄ. E. Tr. 476; παρὰ καιρὸν ἄ. Id. IA 800; ἀριθμός, πρόβατʼ ἄ. Ar. Nu. 1203; ὄχλος ἄ. καὶ βασκανία D. 19.24, cf. Th. 8.78; τὴν ἄ., sc. ἄγουσαν ὁδόν, in vain, λέγειν D. 3.21; ψηφίζεσθαι 19.181, cf. Philem. 51, etc.; also, in no particular way, i.e. concerning indifferent matters, οἱ ἀγῶνες οὐδέποτε τὴν ἄ., ἄλλʼ ἀεὶ τὴν περὶ αὑτοῦ Pl. Tht. 172e; τὴν ἄ. θεωρεῖν Pl. Lg. 650a; τήν γε ἄλλως otherwise, i.e. generally, D.C. 38.24, 42.50:— for nothing, Hdt. 3.139: — otherwise than right, wrongly, D. Ep. 1.12, etc.

data.quote: οἱ ἀγῶνες οὐδέποτε τὴν ἄ., ἄλλʼ ἀεὶ τὴν περὶ αὑτοῦ

children.definition: spring, leap, poet. for Prose πήδημα, Od. 8.103, 128; ἅ. πέτρας, πετραῖον leap or fall from rock, E. HF 1148, Ion 1268; κρημνῶν ἅ. Epigr.Gr. 225 ( Ephesus); οἰκεῖον . . ἅ. ἐπὶ ξίφος E. Hel. 96; κυνῆς ἅ. the leap of the lot from the helmet, S. Aj. 1287; κοῦφον ἅλμα ποδῶν Ἀχιλῆ E. El. 439; track of a comet, Arist. Mete. 343b23.
jumping, as an athletic contest, Simon. 153:—in pl., jumping-ground, τῶν ἁ. τὴν σκάψιν καὶ ὁμάλιξιν BCH 23.566 ( Delph., iii B. C.).

data.quote: τῶν ἁ. τὴν σκάψιν καὶ ὁμάλιξιν

children.label: II
children.definition: pulsation, palpitation, of the embryo, Hp. Alim. 42; of the heart, Id. Cord. 4; f.l. in Pl. Ti. 70d.
Lyc. 319, Epic. ap. Did.ad D. 13.32.
brine, Ar. Fr. 706, Nic. Fr. 70.18: in pl., Dsc. 2.174.
salgamarius (sic), Gloss.
salted, steeped in brine, ἐλάα Ar. Fr. 141: Subst., salted olive, ἐς τὰς ἁ. (sc. ἐλάας) Hermipp. 81, cf. Eup. 255, Ar. Fr. 393, Apollon. ap. Gal. 12.999.
person of tripping gait, Adam. 2.52.
salitores, Gloss.
become mildewed, cj. in Thphr. HP 7.5.4, 8.10.1, CP 6.10.5.
pickling, Dsc. 3.77 (pl.).
seller of pickled fruit, Dsc. 1.29.
steep in brine, pickle, Dsc. 2.111 ( Pass.).
sea-water, brine, Od. 5.53, Pi. P. 2.80, etc.; spray that has dried on the skin, Od. 6.219; salt incrustation on soil, Hdt. 2.12, Thphr. CP 6.10.4.
Hom., brine, i.e. the sea, Arion l. 3, Pi. P. 4.39, A. Pers. 397, Tim. Pers. 96, etc.

salt-water, brine used for pickling, Hdt. 2.77, Ar. V. 1515, Fr. 416; ἡ Θασία ἅ. Cratin. 6; ἐν ἅλμῃ ἕψειν [τὸν ἰχθύν] Antiph. 222, cf. Eub. 44; καταπνίγειν Sotad.Com. 1.21, etc.: prov., πρὶν τοὺς ἰχθῦς ἑλεῖν σὺ τὴν ἅλμην κυκᾷς ‘first catch your hare, then cook it’, Phot. s.v. πρίν.

children.label: II
children.definition: saltness, esp. as a bad quality in soil, X. Oec. 20.12, cf. Thphr. CP 6.10.4.
salt soil, PLond. 2.267.95, al. (i/ii A. D.).
salt, briny, πόρος ἁ., i.e. the sea, A. Supp. 844 (lyr.) codd. ( -ιόεις Herm.).
salted provisions, Men. 462.5.
to be made salt, ὑπὸ θαλάσσης Sch. Il. 2.538, cf. Zos.Alch. p.248B.
drinking of brine, Afric. Cest. 2 (pl.).
drinking brine, Menipp. ap. Ath. 1.32e.
Dim. of ἁλμυρίς 1.3a, Plin. HN 19.142.
to be saltish, Arist. HA 613a3; πρὸς τὴν γεῦσιν Dsc. 2.129.
anything salt, and so,
salt humour, Hp. Epid. 3.13; salt scum, Arist. Mete. 357b4.
salt soil or land, Thphr. CP 2.5.4, LXX Jb. 39.6, PPetr. 3p.237, etc.; in Attica, = ἁλίπεδον, IG 2.1059, Hsch.: pl., Ἁλμῡρίδες, Ar. Fr. 132.
κράμβη, Brassica cretica, Eudem. ap. Ath. 9. 369e, POxy. 736.73 (i B. C.): pl., Diocl. Fr. 138, Plu. Praec. 2.801a.

children.label: II
children.definition: saltness, D.S. 3.39.
= foreg. [ἁλμυρίς] I.2 [ salt soil or land,], Zopyr. ap. Orib. 14.62.1.
with salt soil, πεδιάς Ph. 2.111.

salt, briny, Hom. only in Od., and always in phrase ἁ. ὕδωρ salt sea-water, 4.511, etc.; πόντος Hes. Th. 107, Alc. 26; θάλασσα Sapph. 96.10 L.-P.; καθʼ ἁ. ἅλα Epich. 53, E. Tr. 76; βένθεα Pi. O. 7.57; ποταμός, of the Hellespont, Hdt. 7.35.

salt, γίνεται τὸ στόμα ἁ. Hp. Acut.(Sp.) 44 (not found); ὄψα ἀ. X. Cyr. 6.2.31, cf. Hp. Vict. 1.56; αἷμα Pl. Ti. 84a s.v.l.; of drinking-water, brackish, Th. 4.26; of soil, Thphr. CP 6.10.1, LXX Je. 17.6; opp. μῶρος (insipid), Com.Adesp. 596.
bitter, distasteful, γειτόνημα Alcm. 116, cf. Pl. Lg. 705a; ἀκοή Phdr. 243d; λόγοι Ath. 3.121e; ἁλμυρὰ κλαίειν weep bitterly, Theoc. 23.34; ἁλμυρὸν καταπτύσαι Cerc. 19.37.

children.label: b
children.definition: piquant, ἁ. καὶ δριμύ Plu. QConv. 2.685e.
saltness, Arist. Mete. 356b4.
make salt, θάλασσαν Olymp. in Mete. 152.9.
saltish, ῥεῦμα Hp. Epid. 1.4.5 [1.26.εʹ]; πτύαλον Id. Coac. 238, cf. X. Oec. 20.12 ( Comp.); of soil, impregnated with salt, Thphr. HP 8.7.6; hoary, χνοῦς Id. CP 6.10.7.

definition: ἄλξ πῆχυς (Athaman.), Hsch. (cod. ἄλαξ). ἄλξεων· τειχέων, Id. ἀλξίας· πράξεις, καὶ ἐκλήψεις, Id.

children.definition: threshing-floor, X. Oec. 18.5 (v.l. -ητός).

definition: ἀλοάω, Ep. ἀλοιάω Theoc. 10.48: Ep. impf. ἀλοία Il. 9.568: fut. -ήσω LXX Je. 5.17, Dor. ἀλοιησέω Tyrt. in Berl.Sitzb. 1918.728: aor. ἠλόησα Ar. Ra. 149, Herod. 2.34 ( ἀλοιήσῃ ib. 51), part. ἀλοάσας [ᾱς] Pherecr. 65; Ep. ἠλοίησα ( ἀπ-) Il. 4.522, ( συν-) Theoc. 22.128:— Pass., fut. -ηθήσομαι LXX Je. 28(51).33: aor. ἠλοήθην Thphr. CP 4.6.5, Plb. 10.12.9, Plu. Alex. fort. 2.327a: pf. ἠλόημαι Thphr. CP 4.12.9 (Cod. Urb.):— poet. aor. part. ἀλοίσας (as if from ἀλοίω, cf. Eust. 775.8, Hdn. Epim. 277) dub. l. in Epigr. ap. D.L. 7.31; ἀλοϝάω dub. in Glotta 4.202 (archaic Apulian vase):—

children.definition: tread, thresh, Pl. Thg. 124a, X. Oec. 18.2, LXX De. 25.4.
thresh, smite, γῆν χερσὶν ἀλοία Il. 9.568, cf. Epigr. l.c.; μηρόν Plu. TG 2; cudgel, thrash, Glotta l.c., S. Fr. 20 (dub.), Ar. Ra. 149, Herod. 2.34; ῥοπάλῳ τινά Babr. 98.15.
crush, smash, σκεύη Id. 129.16; destroy, πόλεις LXX Je. 5.17.

children.label: II
children.definition: drive round and round, like cattle treading out corn, Ar. Th. 2 (acc. to Sch.).
with lobe wanting, of livers of victims, ἄ. ἱερά X. HG 3.4.15, Plu. Ages. 9, Arr. An. 7.18.4.
speak casually, Cic. Att. 6.4.3.
not collected, PLond. 2.354.22 (i B. C.).

pay no regard to thing, εἰ δέ μοι οὐκ ἐπέεσσʼ ἐπιπείσεται, ἀλλʼ ἀλογήσει Il. 15.162: c. gen., δίκης Democr. 174; πάσης συμβουλίης Hdt. 3.125; τῶν ἐντολέων Id. 8.46: abs., ib. 116: c. acc., Procop. Pers. 1.4, al.; insult, PTeb. 138 (ii B. C.):— Pass., to feel slighted, Cic. Att. 12.3.3.

data.quote: εἰ δέ μοι οὐκ ἐπέεσσʼ ἐπιπείσεται, ἀλλʼ ἀλογήσει

children.definition: to be unreasonable, Phld. Ir. p.34 W.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be disregarded, D.L. 1.32; commit an indiscretion, be misled, διά τινος miscalculate, Plb. 8.36.4, cf. 28.9.8.
to be out of oneʼs senses, Luc. Ocyp. 143; ἠλογημένη ‘nonplussed’, Alciphr. 2.1; ἠ. ψυχή Hierocl. in CA 12p.446M.
to be irregularly formed, A.D. Adv. 162.18, al., EM 405.34, etc.
miscalculation, error, Plb. 12.20.2: in pl., 9.16.5, al.
one must take no heed of, τινός Ph. 1.312.
Lib. Decl. 16.31 (s.v.l.).

want of respect or regard, ἀλογίην εἶχον τοῦ χρηστηρίου took no heed of it, Hdt. 4.150; ἐν ἀλογίῃ ἔχειν or ποιεῖσθαί τι 6.75, 7.226:—in 2.141 ἐν ἀλογίῃσι ἔχειν παραχρησάμενον τῶν Αἰγυπτίων, gen. is anacoluthon (as if ἀλογίην ἔχειν τῶν Αἰγ.) ; ἀλογίης ἐγκυρῆσαι to be disregarded, 7.208 codd.:—this sense is Ion. and late Prose, ἐν ἀλογίᾳ ποιεῖσθαί τι Procop. Pers. 1.2, al.
Att., want of reason, absurdity, opp. λόγος, Pl. Tht. 207c, cf. 199d, Phd. 67e, D. 23.168; πολλὴ ἀ. τῆς διανοίας Th. 5.111; concrete, the irrational part of the soul, Porph. Abst. 1.42.
confusion, disorder, Plb. 15.14.2; τύχη ἐν ἀλογίᾳ κειμένη Plot. 6.8.17:— speechlessness, amazement, Plb. 36.7.4.
indecision, doubt, Paus. 7.17.6.
irrationality, relation of time-elements which cannot be expressed by a simple ratio, Aristox. Rhyth. 2.20.
to be irrational, Eust. 1656.43, etc.:— Act. only as f.l. for ἀλογέω, Procop. Goth. 4.20.

definition: ἀλογίου δίκη prosecution of a public official

children.definition: for not having his accounts passed, Eup. 349.
unheeded, unprovided for, τῇ προνοίᾳ Hierocl. Prov. p.466B.
lose oneʼs senses, rave, Plu. QConv. 2.656d, Longin. 10.3, Vett.Val. 130.30.
thoughtlessly, Harp., AB 380.
thoughtlessness, Democr. 289, Plb. 5.15.3, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.129, Phld. Ir. p.93 W., Plu. Tranq. 2.466c.
inconsiderate, thought-less, τόλμα Th. 3.82; ὀργή Men. 574; of persons, Phld. Ir. p.97 W. Adv. -τως thoughtlessly, Lys. 7.12, Isoc. 2.29; δαπανᾶν ἀ. βίον Men. 623, etc.

irrational, Pl. Ap. 37c; opp. λογιστικός, R. 439d, al.; foolish, unthinking, Phld. Ir. p.97 W.; πλοῦτος ἀ. προσλαβὼν ἐξουσίαν Men. 665; τὸ ἀ. unreason, i.e. chance, Th. 5.99. Adv. -τως Id. 3.45, Pl. Prt. 324b, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: incalculable, S. OC 1675 (lyr.); indefinite, indeterminate, φορά Procl. in Prm. p.547 S.
not to be accounted, vile, E. Or. 1156, Men. 75.
undescribed, Eust. 888.49.
irrational, ἀ. τὴν ψυχήν Dam. Pr. 401.
of which no account is given, Gloss.
horse-fly, Anon. in Rh. 125.10.
to be rendered irrational, Plot. 5.3.10 (prob. l.); [φύσις] ἠλογωμένη non-rational, Procl. in Prm. p.617 S.
irrational affection, Plot. 4.4.28 (pl.).
unreasonably, Eustr. in EN 275.8.
without λόγος, hence,

children.label: I
children.definition: speechless, Pl. Lg. 696e. Adv. -ως without speech, S. OC 131, Isoc. 3.9:— ἄ. ἡμέρα, = Lat. dies nefastus, on which no business may be done, Luc. Lex. 9.

children.label: b
children.definition: lacking in eloquence, LXX Ex. 6.12.
inexpressive, Pl. Tht. 203a; unutterable, = ἄρρητος, S. Fr. 262.

children.label: II
children.definition: unreasoning, ἡδονή, ὄχλος, etc., Pl. R. 591c, Ti. 42d, etc.; τὰ ἄλογα brutes, animals, Democr. 164, Pl. Prt. 321b, X. Hier. 7.3; esp. in late Greek, ἄλογον, τό, = horse, POxy. 138.29 (610 A.D.), PGen. 14 (late).

not according to reason, irrational, ἄ. δόξα, opp. ἡ μετὰ λόγου δ., Pl. Tht. 201c; ἀλόγῳ πάθει τὴν ἄ. συνασκεῖν αἴσθησιν, instinctive feeling, in appreciating works of art, D.H. Lys. 11; ἄ. πάθος Id. Comp. 23.

contrary to reason, absurd, Th. 6.85, Pl. Tht. 203d; unaccountable, unintelligible, Lys. 26.19; unfit, unsuited to its end, Th. 1.32; groundless, Plb. 3.15.9; ἀηδία PRyl. 144.15 (38 A.D.). Adv. most freq. in this sense, Pl. R. 439d, etc.; οὐκ ἀ. οὐδʼ ἀκαίρως Isoc. 15.10: Sup. -ώτατα Phld. Ir. p.44 W.

children.label: III
children.definition: without reckoning:
not reckoned upon, unexpected, Th. 6.46 ( Comp.).
not counted, null and void, ἡμέραι LXX Nu. 6.12.
Act., not having paid oneʼs reckoning, of an ἐρανιστής, EM 70.31.

children.label: IV
children.definition: incommensurable, περὶ ἀλόγων γραμμῶν, title of work by Democr., cf. Arist. APo. 76b9, LI 968b18, Euc. 10. Def. 10, etc.

irrational, of feet or syllables whose time-relations cannot be expressed by a simple ratio, χορεῖος Aristox. Rhyth. 2.20; ἄλογοι, sc. συλλαβαί, D.H. Comp. 20:—in Music, ἄ. διαστήματα Plu. Mus. 2.1145d:—of the pulse, unrhythmical, Herophil. ap. Ruf. Syn.Puls. 4.3.

definition: ἀλογχεῖν Ἀλόγχους μιμεῖσθαι, ὅ ἐστι ἔθνος Θρᾳκῶν, Hsch.

children.definition: without lances or weapons, ἄ. ἀνθέων στρατός Chaerem. 10.

children.definition: without a head, Hsch., EM 70.36.
unlucky, opp. εὔλογχος (q.v.), sc. ἡμέρα, prob. l. in Democr. ap. Gem. Calend. 8.
irrational, v.l. Arist. Spir. 481b27 ( Comp.); τὰ -έστερα ψυχῶν γένη Procl. in Cra. p.69 P.
bitter aloes, Aloe vera, Dsc. 3.22, Plu. Coniug. 2.141f, etc.
LXX Ca. 4.15 (in Heb. form ἀλώθ), Ev.Jo. 19.39.

purgative prepared from aloes, Aët. 3.100, al.
threshing, Gloss.:— ἀλοίησις, EM 74.22.
threshing, PLond. 1.113(3).8 (vi A.D.), BGU 840 (vi A.D.).

threshing, Ael. NA 6.43; threshing-time, LXX Le. 26.5, BGU 1031.11 (ii A.D.): perh. payment for threshing, PTeb. 48.17 (ii B.C.).
payment for threshing, PFlor. 379.18 (ii A.D.), prob. in BGU 698.27 (ii A.D.).
from the sea, ἐξ ἁλόθεν Il. 21.335.
salt-box, Hdn.Gr. 2.418.

definition: ἅλοι πηλοί, Hsch. ἀλοιάω, Ep. for ἀλοάω.

irreproachable, IG 14.2139, 12(7).395 ( Amorgos), Plu. Util. 2.89a.

avenger, Emp. 10:—fem. Ἀλοῖτις, ιδος, ἡ, of Athena, Lyc. 936: but ἀλοῖτις, ἡ, = γεντιανή, Ps.- Dsc. 3.3; = μανδραγόρα ἄρρεν, Id. 4.75.

definition: ἀλοιτός, ὁ, (ἀλιτεῖν) = ἀλείτης, Lyc. 136: fem. ἀλοιταί· κοιναί, ἁμαρτωλαί, ποιναί (cf. ἀλοίτης), Hsch.

daub with pitch, κιβωτόν Aq. Ge. 6.14.
anointing-room, Eust. 764.14.
anything with which one can smear or anoint; esp. hogʼs-lard, grease, either in carcase, Il. 9.208, or when melted for use, 17.390.
paint, varnish, etc., Pl. Criti. 116b, cf. IG 2(2).463.85, LXX Mi. 7.11, etc.; νεώς Polyaen. 5.34.

Anaxandr. 41.7; γῆ Pl. Phd. 110c; τὸ ἁ. Arist. Col. 792a7:—less freq. ἁλουργός, όν (also ά, όν Phylarch. 41), ἔρια Pl. R. 429d; χιτωνίσκος IG 2.754.12,14, etc. (but χ. ἁλουργής ib. 21); στολαί Phylarch. l.c.; στρωμναί Plu. Lyc. 12, AB 81:—also ἁλουργοῦς, οῦν, IG 2.757, v.l. in Arist. Sens. 442a24, Ion. ἁλοργοῦς GDI 5702.23 ( Samos).

purple robe, Ar. Eq. 967, IG 2.754, Chamaeleon ap. Ath. 9.374a.

children.definition: without birth-pangs, αὖλαξ κόσμου ib. 24.269, cf. 41.53.

leman, concubine, Il. 9.336, Od. 4.623.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀ- priv.) unwedded, ἄ. οὖσα τὴν λοχείαν εἴληχε, of Artemis, Pl. Tht. 149b, cf. Porph. ad Il. 11.155.

definition: ἀλόω, Ep. imper. of ἀλάομαι, Od. 5.377.
ἄλπνιστος, η, ον, Sup. of ἄλπνος (only in compd. ἔπαλπνος, q.v.),

children.definition: sweetest, loveliest, Pi. I. 5(4).12; cf. ἀλπαλέον (cod. -αῖον) · ἀγαπητόν, Hsch. (Cf. ἔλπω ( ϝέλπω), Lat. volup.)

definition: ἅλς (A), ἁλός [ᾰ], ὁ: dat. pl. ἅλασιν (v. infr.):—

children.definition: salt, πάσσε δʼ ἁλὸς θείοιο Il. 9.214, cf. Od. 17.455; ἁλὸς μέταλλον a salt-mine, Hdt. 4.185; ἁλὸς χόνδροι lumps of rock-salt, ib. 181 : sg. also Ar. Ach. 835, Philyll. 28, Axionic. 8: more freq. in pl., Od. 11.123, Hdt. 4.53, al., etc.:—prov. phrases: οὐ σύ γʼ ἂν . . σῷ ἐπιστάτη οὐδʼ ἅλα δοίης Od. 17.455; φῄς μοι πάντα δόμεν· τάχα δʼ . . οὐδʼ ἅλα δοίης Theoc. 27.61; ἅλας συναναλῶσαι, i.e. to be bound by ties of hospitality, Arist. EN 1156b27; τῶν ἁλῶν συγκατεδηδοκέναι μέδιμνον to have eaten a bushel of salt together, i.e. to be old friends, Com.Adesp. 176; οἱ περὶ ἅλα καὶ κύαμον, of friends, Plu. QConv. 2.684e, cf. Arist. EE 1238a3; ὅρκον μέγαν, ἅλας τε καὶ τράπεζαν Archil. 96; ποῦ ἅλες; ποῦ τράπεζαι; D. 19.189; τοὺς ἅλας παραβαίνειν ib. 191; τοὺς τῆς πόλεως ἅλας περὶ πλείονος ποιήσασθαι τῆς ξενικῆς τραπέζης Aeschin. 3.224; ἁλῶν δὲ φόρτος ἔνθεν ἦλθεν, ἔνθʼ ἔβη ‘light come, light go’, Zen. 2.20; ἅλασιν ὕει, of great abundance, Suid.

data.quote: οὐ σύ γʼ ἂν . . σῷ ἐπιστάτη οὐδʼ ἅλα δοίης
φῄς μοι πάντα δόμεν· τάχα δʼ . . οὐδʼ ἅλα δοίης
ὅρκον μέγαν, ἅλας τε καὶ τράπεζαν
τοὺς τῆς πόλεως ἅλας περὶ πλείονος ποιήσασθαι τῆς ξενικῆς τραπέζης

children.label: II
children.definition: brine, Call. Fr. 50.

children.label: III
children.definition: ἃ. ἀμμωνιακός rock-salt, PLond. 1.78.90.
ἃ. Ἰνδικός sugar, Archig. ap. Paul.Aeg. 2.53.

children.label: IV
children.definition: ἅλες, οἱ, metaph., like Lat. sales, wit, possible but unlikely in Pl. Smp. 177b, Ep.Col. 4.6; certain in Plu. Comp. Arist. Men. 2.854c; ἅλες called “ χάριτες” QConv. ib. 685a. (Cf. sq.)

definition: ἅλς (B), ἁλός [ᾰ], ἡ ( ἁλὸς πολιοῖο Il. 20.229),

children.definition: sea (generally of shallow water near shore), εἰς ἅλα δῖαν Il. 1.141; χεῖρας νιψάμενος πολιῆς ἁλός in sea-water, Od. 2.261; ἢ ἁλὸς ἢ ἐπὶ γῆς 12.27: sts. pleonast. πόντος ἁλός Il. 21.59, Thgn. 10; ἁλὸς πελάγη or πέλαγος, Od. 5.335, h.Ap. 73, E. Tr. 88; πελαγίαν ἅλα A. Pers. 427; παρʼ ἁλμυρὰν ἅλα E. Ba. 17; in pl. (with a pun on ἅλς A), Ar. Ach. 760.—Poet. word: nom. only Emp. 56. (Cf. Lat. sal: both masc. and fem. are from the same root.)

definition: Ἄλσειος, ὁ, sc. μήν, month at Cos, SIG 1023.25.

children.definition: of the grove, νύμφαι A.R. 1.1066.
lich-wort, Parietaria lusitanica, Thphr. HP 9.13.3, Dsc. 4.86.
leaping, Hp. Morb.Sacr. 17, Arist. EN 1174a31, Antyll. ap. Orib. 6.31.5, etc.
growth, Did. ad D. 13.32, Apollon. Lex. s.v. ἀλδαίνει, etc.
to be keeper of a grove or precinct:—also ἀλσο-κομία, ἡ;

children.label: b
children.definition: ἀλσοκομικός, ή, όν, (ἀλσοκομική, ἡ, sc. τέχνη) Adv. -κῶς Poll. 7.141:—
planting of groves, Poll. 7.140
grove, Il. 20.8, Od. 10.350: pl., Phanocl. 1.3, Theoc. 1.117, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: sacred grove, Od. 6.291, Hes. Sc. 99, Hdt. 5.119, Pl. Lg. 761c, etc.:—hence, any hallowed precinct, even without trees, Il. 2.506, Sch. Pi. O. 3.31, cf. B. 3.19, S. Ant. 844; Μαραθώνιον ἄ., of the field of battle, viewed as a holy place, A. Eleg. 4: metaph., πόντιον ἄ. the ocean- plain, B. 16.85, A. Pers. 111. (Perh. for ἄλτ-ιος (cf. Ἄλτις), i.e. alq-ios, cf. Goth. alhs ‘temple’.)
woodland, κρῆναι E. IA 141 (lyr.); τόποι Nic. Thyat. ap. Ath. 11.503c, Dsc. 4.86.

children.label: II
children.definition: growing in woods, of plants, Thphr. HP 3.2.4, LXX 4 Ki. 16.4, Hecat.Abd. ap. J. Ap. 1.22, Plu. QConv. 2.648c.

definition: ἀλσών, ῶνος, ὁ, = ἄλσωμα, (= ἄλσος) Aq. 4 Ki. 17.16.
ἀλτεῖ ἀπορεῖ, Hsch. (leg. ἀλύει). ἀλτηρεία· ἁφὴ τῆς χειρός, Id.
ἁλτῆρες, ων, οἱ (sg., Philostr. Gym. 55), ( ἅλλομαι)

children.definition: weights held in the hand to give an impetus in leaping, Crates Com. 11, Arist. IA 705a16, Pr. 881b5, etc.
use of ἁλτῆρες, Artemid. 1.57.
good at leaping, X. Cyr. 8.4.20; τὰ ἁ. μόρια parts used in leaping, Arist. PA 683b3; ἁ. ὄρχησις, of the Salii, Plu. Num. 13.
sacred precinct of Zeus at Olympia, Pi. O. 10(11).50, X. HG 7.4.29, etc.: Elean for ἄλσος, Paus. 5.10.1.

definition: ἄλτο πολύ, ἐλαφρόν, Hsch. ἀλτὸς καὶ ἀλτρός μισθός, Id. ἄλυγος· ἄνευ μάστιγος, Id. ἀλύδαινος· ὁ κακὸς ἄνεμος, Suid.

children.definition: Sophr. 139.

senses.definition: socket for ἐχέτλη, q.v., Eratosth. ap. EM 173.24; dub. l. Phld. Mort. p.318M.

children.definition: salting, Ptol. Tetr. 181.
Hp. Aph. 7.56, al.
salt-spring, Str. 4.1.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: saltness, Plu. 2.897a.
salt, Hp. Acut. 42, Aër. 1, Ar. Lys. 403, LXX Ge. 14.3; brackish, Thphr. HP 4.3.5.
myrrh, Hippiatr. 52.
saltness, Arist. Fr. 217, Thphr. CP 2.5.4, Mnesith. ap. Ath. 3.92b.
lukewarm, Call. Fr. 270 Pf., Nic. Al. 386 ( Comp.); cf. ἀλυκτρόν.

wander distraught, B. 10.93; to be distressed, Hdt. 9.70:—also ἀλυκτέω, to be in distress, anguish, Hp. Mul. 1.5, cf. Erot., EM 71.38, Hsch., Suid.: aor. part. ἀλυκτήσας in act. sense, = θορυβήσας, Hsch., EM 71.39; cf. ἀλαλύκτημαι.

bonds, in pl., Hes. Th. 521, A.R. 2.1249: sg., AP 5.229 ( Paul.Sil.), etc. ( ἀλυκτο- prob. = unbreakable, cf. Skt. rujáli ‘break’, but taken by late Poets as = ἀλυτο- indissoluble, cf. Paul.Sil. l.c., AP 9.641 ( Agath.), Nonn. D. 21.56.)
to be shunned, φόνοι Epigr.Gr. 793 (Phryg.):—wrongly expl. by ἄφυκτος, Suid., Zonar.
Suid.
Hsch.

definition: ἀλυκτρόν εὔδινον, Hsch. ἀλύνει· φύει, Id.

children.definition: like salt, saltish, γλῶσσα Hp. Acut.(Sp.) 2 (1); φλοιός Thphr. HP 9.11.2 (ubi ἁλικώδης).
unhurt, unimpaired, Plu. Lib.educ. 2.5e, Porph. ap. Eus. PE 11.28.
to be free from pain, imper. ἀλύπει IG 14.1030, etc.; prob. l. in Phld. Rh. 1.373S.
not pained or grieved, S. Tr. 168.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., not causing pain, S. OC 1662 (but v. sub ἀλάμπετος): so Adv. -τως Pl. Lg. 958e.
freedom from pain or grief, Antipho Soph. ap. Plu. VOrat. 2.833c, Pl. Ax. 371d, Men. 549, Arist. Rh. 1365b13, Epicur. Fr. 120, Sotad. 5.10, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: digestibility, Thphr. HP 2.4.2.

definition: ἀλυπιάς, ἡ, = ἄλυπος III, Paul.Aeg. 7.4, Alex.Trall. 1.15.

children.definition: without pain, freq. in Trag. (not A.), E. IA 163, etc.: c. gen., ἄ. γήρως without pains of age, S. OC 1519; ἄ. ἄτης El. 1002; βίος E. Ba. 1004; ἀρχή S. OT 593; τὸ ἄ. Pl. R. 585a: Comp. -ότερος ib. 581e: Sup. -ότατος Lg. 848e. Adv. ἀλύπως, ζῆν, διατελεῖν live free from pain and sorrow, Id. Prt. 358b, Phlb. 43d, cf. Men. 549; ἀποθανεῖν Id. 14: Sup. ἀλυπότατα Lys. 24.10.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., causing no pain or grief, Hp. Art. 39 ( Sup.), Pl. Plt. 272a, etc.; ἄ. οἶνος harmless, Hermipp. 82.5, cf. E. Ba. 423; ἄ. ἄνθος ἀνίας setting free from the pain of sorrow of wine, S. Fr. 172; ἀλυπότατος κλιντήρ, of a hospice, Epigr.Gr. 450 ( Batanaea); σωλῆνες -ότατοι μετὰ ἁλῶν cause least pain, i.e. are least indigestible, Xenocr. 57, cf. Mnesith. ap. Ath. 3.92c; πεσσὸς -ότατος Aët. 16.36. Adv. ἀλύπως, τοῖς ἄλλοις ζῆν live without offence to others, Isoc. 12.5.

children.label: III
children.definition: ἄλυπον, τό, herb terrible, Globularia Alypum, Plin. HN 27.22, Dsc. 4.178.

without the lyre, unaccompanied by it, ὕμνοι ἄ., i.e. wild dirges (accompanied by flute, not lyre), E. Alc. 447; ἄ. ἔλεγος Hel. 185; μέλος Poet. ap. Arist. Rh. 1408a7; Ἄϊδος μοῖρʼ ἄ., of death, S. OC 1223 (lyr.); ἄ. φθόγγοι sad talk, Alex. 162.6 (anap.); ἄ. μαθήματα ποιητῶν Pl. Lg. 810b.
agitation, Hp. Ep. 1, Gal. 9.613; χειρῶν Adam. 2.21.

children.label: II
children.definition: ennui, boredom, Zeno Stoic. 1.58, Plu. Eum. 11, Diog.Oen. Fr. 24; ἄ. ναυτιώδης Plu. Pyrrh. 13.
in chains, Man. 4.486.
Nic. Th. 427, EM 70.45, prob. in Hp. Morb. 2.54, 58, 67; cf. ἀλυσταίνω.
bound with chains, Hsch.

definition: ἁλυσίδιον or ἀλυσ-είδιον, τό, Dim. of ἅλυσις, Hero Spir. 1.38, Ph. 2.152, POxy. 496.3 (ii A. D.), AB 380.

children.definition: wrought in chain fashion, ἁ. θώραξ Plb. 6.23.15 (pl), D.S. 5.30, etc.; opp. λινοθώραξ, στάδιος θώραξ, Str. 3.3.6, Sch. A.R. 3.1226.

definition: ἁλύσιον, τό, Dim. of sq., Men. 258, Philippid. 33, PHib. 1.121.3 (iii B. C.), PMeyer 22.6 (iii/iv A.D.).
ἅλυσις (on the breathing v. Hdn.Gr. 1.539), εως, ἡ,

children.definition: chain, χαλκέῃ ἁλύσι δεδεμένη ἄγκυρα Hdt. 9.74, cf. Th. 2.76, etc.; ἐν ἁλύσει μιᾷ δεδεμένους D.Chr. 30.17, cf. Ep.Eph. 6.20; πέτραν ἁλύσεσι χρυσέαισι φερομέναν E. Or. 982:—as a womanʼs ornament, Ar. Fr. 320.12, Nicostr. 33; σφραγῖδε . . ἁλύσεις χρυσᾶς ἔχουσαι IG 2.652B35.
chains, bondage, Plb. 21.3.3.
link in chain armour, Arr. Tact. 3.5.
distress, anguish, Dsc. 5.2; gloss on ἀλυσμός, Gal. 19.75.
damage, prejudice, Plb. 4.47.1.
unprofitable, Pl. Cra. 417d, X. Oec. 14.5, Polystr. p.18 W.; of a person, ἀ. τῇ πόλει Bato 2.9: Sup. -έστατος Aeschin. 1.105. Adv. -λῶς X. Mem. 1.7.2, Hierocl. in CA 12p.447M., etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: unfavourable, of symptoms, Hp. Prog. 14.

definition: ἀλυσκάζω, strengthd. for ἀλύσκω (from which it borrows obl. tenses); irreg. opt. ἀλυσκάζειε Nonn. D. 42.135, al.:—

children.definition: shun, avoid, c. acc., ὕβριν ἀλυσκάζειν Od. 17.581: abs., skulk, Il. 5.253, 6.443, Orph. A. 437; dub. in Hes. Fr. 96.94.— Ep. word, used by Cratin. 137.

definition: ἀλύσκω, Od. 22.363: fut. ἀλύξω Il. 10.371, A. Pers. 94, S. Ant. 488, etc.; ἀλύξομαι v.l. in Hes. Op. 363: aor. ἤλυξα, poet. ἄλυξα, v. infr.:— Med. in compd. ἐξαλύσκω.— Ep. Verb used by A. and S., both in lyr. and dialogue (also in late Prose, Philostr. Her. 7):—

children.definition: flee from, shun, c. acc., Il. 10.371, Od. 12.335, Hes. l.c., Pi. P. 8.16, A. Pr. 587, etc.: rarely c. gen., S. Ant. 488, El. 627: abs., escape, ὅθεν οὔπως ἦεν ἀλύξαι Od. 22.460; προτὶ ἄστυ ἀλύξαι Il. 10.348; ἄλυξεν ἐν Γερήνῳ he escaped by staying in Gerenus, Hes. Fr. 16.

children.label: II
children.definition: wander restlessly, A.R. 4.57.
anguish, disquiet: esp. tossing about, of sick persons, Hp. Prog. 3, al.
uneasy, troubled, Hp. Coac. 296.
madwort, Farsetia clypeata, Dsc. 3.91 ( ἀλύσσιον Ps.- Dsc. l.c.), cf. Plu. QConv. 2.648a.
Galenʼs madwort, Sideritis romana, Ruf. Fr. 76.10; cf. sq. [ἄλυσσος]
curing madness, βοτάνη ( = foreg. 2) Asclep. ap. Gal. 14.168; πηγὴ ἄ. well (in Arcadia) curing hydrophobia, Paus. 8.19.3.
to be uneasy, restless, pres. only Il. 22.70 ἀ. περὶ θυμῷ: fut., ἀλύξει τε καὶ ῥίψει ἑαυτήν will be restless . . , Hp. Mul. 1.2: plpf. Pass., κραδίη ἀλάλυκτο φόβῳ was disquieted, Q.S. 14.24.
hold office of ἀλυτάρχης, Inscr.Olymp. 468, BCH 28.82 ( Tralles).
chief of police at Olympic games, Luc. Herm. 40, Inscr.Olymp. 240; ἀ. τῶν μεγάλων Ὀλυμπίων BCH 28.81 ( Tralles), cf. Cod.Theod. 15.9.2 ( Antioch.).
office of ἀλυτάρχης, Cod.Just. 1 36.1; cf. ἀλύτης.
police-officer at Olympic games (and elsewhere), Inscr.Olymp. 483, EM 72.14.
pediculus, Apul. Herb. 81.

definition: ἄλυτος, ον, poet. ἄλλυτος Phanocl. 2.1, AP 6.30 ( Maced.),

children.definition: not to be loosed or broken, indissoluble, πέδαι, δεσμοί, Il. 13.37, Od. 8.275, A. Pr. 55; ἀδάμας AP 12.93 ( Rhian.); Μοιράων νῆμα Phanocl. l.c., cf. Epigr.Gr. 520 ( Thessalonica); πτολέμοιο πεῖραρ Il. 13.360; κύκλος (of the wheel of the ἴϋγξ) Pi. P. 4.215; irremediable, S. El. 230 (lyr.): of substances, insoluble, Arist. Mete. 384b7. Adv. -τως Pl. Ti. 60c.
not to be confuted, irrefutable, Arist. Rh. 1357b17, 1403a14; συλλογισμός Arist. APr. 70a29.

children.label: II
children.definition: undissolved, Pl. Ti. 60e.
threshing implement, PAmh. 2.143.14 (iv A. D.).
not redeemed, Sm. Le. 25.23.
Gal. 19.76, cf. Hsch., who also has ἄλυχα· ἀδημονία; cf. ἀλύκη.
without lamp or light, E. Fr. 411, D.L. 1.81.

definition: ἀλύω, Att. ἁλύω acc. to Suid., cf. Eust. 1636.28, Aeol. ἀλυίω EM 254.16; only pres. and impf.; Poet. (rare in Com.) and late Prose:—

children.definition: to be deeply stirred, excited:
to be distraught, beside oneself, ἡ δʼ ἀλύουσʼ ἀπεβήσετο Il. 5.352; δινεύεσκʼ ἀλύων παρὰ θῖνα 24.12; ἀλύων in mad passion, Od. 9.398; ἐᾶτέ μʼ ὧδʼ ἀλύειν S. El. 135; τί χρῆμʼ ἀλύω; E. Or. 277, etc.

to be at a loss, perplexed, ἀλύει δʼ ἐπὶ παντί S. Ph. 174; ἀλύοντα χειμερίῳ λύπᾳ ib. 1194; ἐν πόνοις ἀλύουσαν Id. OT 695; οἱ μὲν εὐποροῦμεν οἱ δʼ ἀλύομεν are at our witʼs end, Alex. 116.13; ἄλλως ἀλύει is wasting her pains, Men. Epit. 342; ψυχὴ ἀ. διὰ τὴν ἀπορίαν Plu. Brut. 15.

data.quote: οἱ μὲν εὐποροῦμεν οἱ δʼ ἀλύομεν

children.definition: to be weary, ennuyé, ἐπὶ τῶν συμποσίων Metrod. Herc. 831.13, cf. Plu. Sollert. 2.965a, Ael. VH 14.12.
to be fretful, restless, Hp. Epid. 1.4.1 [1.26.αʹ], Men. Epit.Fr. 4, Gal. 18(1).167.
to be beside oneself, Od. 18.333, A. Th. 391, cf. Jac. AP p.760.

children.label: II
children.definition: wander, roam about, Plb. 26.1.1, Luc. DMar. 13.1, Plu. TG 21; lounge idly, Babr. 9. [11].

children.label: III
children.definition: to be distraught at, τῶν σκελῶν .. τὴν ἧτταν ἀλυόντων Hld. 10.30.4, μετὰ φρεσὶν ἄχθος ἀλύει Opp. H. 4.195. [ ῠ Hom., except at the end of the verse, Od. 9.398, as A.R. 3.866; ἀλῡοντες in 4th foot, Emp. 145, Opp. H. 4.195; ῡ always in Trag.]

definition: ἄλφα, τό, indecl. (pl. τὰ ἄ. Arist. Metaph. 1087a8),

children.definition: v. Α α init.; cf. Aen.Tact. 31.18, Callias ap. Ath. 10.453d, Pl. Cra. 431e; ἐπίσταται δʼ οὐδʼ ἄλφα συλλαβὴν γνῶναι Herod. 3.22.

children.definition: -square, Eustr. in EN 74.2.
βοὸς κεφαλή, Hsch.
τὸ ἄλφα καὶ τὸ ὦ the first and last, Apoc. 1.8, al.
alphabet, AB 181, Sch.D.T.p.320 H.

definition: ἀλφαδεῖ εὑρίσκει, καὶ ἀλφαίνει, and ἀλφαίει· τὸ αὐτὸ δηλοῖ, Hsch.

children.definition: Dim. of ἄλφα, carpenterʼs square, Eustr. in EN 322.18.

definition: ἀλφάνω [ᾰν] ( ἀλφαίνω EM 72.39, Aët. 13.133), Hom. only in aor. 2 ἦλφον, cf. IG 1.53a15, Plu. QConv. 2.668c: pres., E. Med. 297, Fr. 326 (no-where else in Trag.), Ar. Fr. 324, Eup. 258, Men. 362:—

children.definition: bring in, yield, fetch, ἵνα μοι βίοτον πολὺν ἄλφοι Od. 17.250; ὁ δʼ ὑμῖν μυρίον ὦνον ἄλφοι 15.452, cf. 20.383; ἑκατόμβοιον δέ τοι ἦλφον Il. 21.79; ὁπόσην ἂν ἄλφῃ μίσθωσιν τὸ τέμενος IG l.c., cf. Plu. l.c.: metaph., φθόνον ἀλφάνειν to incur envy, E. Med. 297.

data.quote: ὁ δʼ ὑμῖν μυρίον ὦνον ἄλφοι

children.label: II
children.definition: change, Aët. l.c. (cf. Skt. arghás ‘priceʼ).
Dim. of ἄλφα, plumb-line, level, Theo Sm. in Ptol. p.228 H.

bringing in oxen, παρθένοι ἀ. maidens who yield their parents many oxen as presents from their suitors, i.e. much-courted, Il. 18.593, h.Ven. 119; ὕδωρ ἀ., of the Nile, water that yields fat oxen (by enriching pastures), A. Supp. 855 (lyr.); Πειρήνης ἀ. ὕδωρ Alex.Aet. 3.8: pr. n. Ἀλφεσίβοια used at beginning of trim., S. Fr. 880.
produce, gain, Lyc. 549,1394.

definition: ἀλφηστής, οῦ, ὁ, Hom. only in Od., in phrase ἀνέρες ἀλφησταί, lit.

children.definition: earners ( ἀλφάνω), i.e. enterprising men, Od. 1.349, cf. Hes. Op. 82; esp. of traders or seafarers, Od. 13.261, h.Ap. 458; ἑκὰς ἀνδρῶν ἀλφηστάων, of the Phaeacians, Od. 6.8.— Ep. word, twice in Trag. (lyr.), A. Th. 770, S. Ph. 709.

children.label: II
children.definition: fish that went in pairs, Labrus cinaedus, Epich. 44, Numen. ap. Ath. 7.320e: metaph., of lewd men, Sophr. 63.
Arist. Fr. 307, Diocl. Fr. 135.
indecl. abbrev. of ἄλφιτον, ἄλφι καὶ ὕδωρ h.Cer. 208, cf. Str. 8.5.3, EM 769.39.
Hsch.

definition: ἀλφίσκω, f.l. in Od. 22.57 ap. EM 758.47.

children.definition: dealer in ἄλφιτα, Ar. Av. 491, al.
preparing of ἄλφιτα, Hyp. Fr. 225 ( ἀλφίτια codd. Poll.), Poll. 7.18.
mill for grinding ἄλφιτα, Poll. 3.78, 7.19, AB 261.
barley-miller, Hyp. Fr. 224.
grind barley, Hippon. 46.
like ἄλφιτα, Dsc. Eup. 2.51.

children.label: II
children.definition: where bone is comminuted, Gal. 10.424, Paul.Aeg. 6.89.
of or belonging to ἄλφιτα, ἀγγεῖον ἀ. meal-tub, Antiph. 63 ( -τήριον Poll. 10.179).
ἀλφιτηρὸν ἐργαλεῖα κινεῦσι ‘a living wage for the worker’, Herod. 7.73.
mixing with barley-groats, οἴνου BCH 6.26 ( Delos, ii B. C.).
like ἄλφιτα, Poet. de herb. 77.
one that divines from barley-meal, Iamb. Myst. 3.17, Phryn. PS p.91 B., Poll. 7.188, Hsch.

barley-groats, sg. in Hom. only in phrase ἀλφίτου ἀκτή Il. 11.631, Od. 2.355, 14.429, and Medic., Gal. 6.507: elsewh. in pl. ἄλφιτα, opp. ἀλείατα, q. v., ἄ. μυελὸν ἀνδρῶν Od. 2.290, al., Hdt. 7.119, freq. in Att.; used to sprinkle over roast meat, Il. 18.560, cf. Od. 14.77; esp. over sacrificial victims, Od. 14.429: ἐπʼ ἀλφίτου πίνειν to drink wine with barley-groats in it, Epin. 1:—of this was made a kind of barley-water, πιεῖν ἄλφιτα Hp. Epid. 5.10; also, poultices, Dsc. 4.87: also used as hair-powder by κανηφόροι, Hermipp. 26.

children.label: II
children.definition: meal, groats, ἄ. πύρινα Hp. Acut.(Sp.) 53 (21); ἄ. φακῶν καὶ ὀρόβων Id. Int. 23; even λίθοιο ἄλφιτα Orph. L. 212.

children.label: III
children.definition: oneʼs daily bread, ‘bread and cheese’, Ar. Pl. 219, Nu. 106, etc.
Suid. s.v. τηλία.
preparer of ἄλφιτα, Oenom. ap. Eus. PE 5.34.
seller of ἄλφιτα, Nicoph. 19:—fem. ἀλφῐτό-πωλις, D.L. 6.9, 7.168; as Adj., ἀ. στοά flour-market at Athens, Ar. Ec. 682.

definition: ἀλφιτοπωλήτρια, ἡ, pecul. fem. of ἀλφιτοπώλης, Poll. 6.37.

children.definition: of the meal-sellers, πλατεῖα AB 275.
eat barley-bread, X. Cyr. 6.2.28.
Hsch. ( -σκόπαι cod.).
eating barley-bread, Ael. NA 17.31.
of the colour of barley-meal, κεφαλὴ ἀ. powdered, i.e. mangy head, Ar. Fr. 533.
bugbear with which nurses frightened children, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.77.

definition: Ἀλφιῷος, ὁ, sc. μήν, name of month at Elis, GDI 1168.

children.definition: Philum. Ven. 23.2.
white-faced, and ἀλφό-ρυγχος, ον, with white snout, Hippiatr. 13.
dull-white leprosy, esp. on the face, Hes. Fr. 29, Thphr. Char. 19.2, LXX Le. 13.39, etc.: pl. in Hp. Aph. 3.20, Pl. Ti. 85a. (Cf. Lat. albus.)
leprous, Gal. 6.243, Vett.Val. 13.2.

definition: ἀλχηρής ὕπνος· ἀηδής, οὐκ ἔχων χαράς, Hsch.
Ἁλῶα or Ἁλῷα, ων, τά, ( ἅλως) festival of Demeter as inventress of agriculture,

children.definition: harvest home, IG 2.834bii8, D. 59.116, Philoch. 161, Luc. DMeretr. 7.4.

definition: ἁλωαῖος, α, ον, ( ἅλως) belonging to the threshing-floor: Ἁλωαίη, epith. of Demeter, Orph. H. 41.5.
Ἁλωάς, άδος, or Ἁλωίς, ίδος, ἡ, = Ἁλωαία, belonging to the threshing-floor, epith. of Demeter Theoc. 7.155.

children.definition: unblemished, φύσις Ph. 1.451; intact, ἀ. καὶ ἀκέραιος Them. Or. 3.43c, cf. Zos. 2.5; sound in limb, Gal. 13.1026.
like salt, Plu. QConv. 2.627f.

senses.definition: of or used in a threshing-floor, ἵπποι AP 9.301 ( Secund.).
one who works in an ἀλωή, husbandman, A.R. 3.1401, Arat. 1045, etc.: in Hom. only as pr. n.

definition: ἀλωή [ᾰ], Dor. ἀλωά, ἡ, ( ἀλέωA, cf. Att. ἅλως) poet.:

children.label: I
children.definition: threshing-floor, ἱερὰς κατʼ ἀλωάς Il. 5.499; μεγάλην κατʼ ἀλωήν, ἐϋκτιμένῃ ἐν ἀλωῇ, 13.588, 20.496, cf. Hes. Op. 597.

children.label: II
children.definition: any prepared ground (cf. Sch. Od. 1.193), garden, orchard, vineyard, etc., Il. 5.90, Od. 6.293, etc.: Ποσειδάωνος ἀ., i.e. sea, Opp. H. 1.797.

children.label: III
children.definition: halo, of sun or moon, Arat. 811, 875.
of the threshing-floor, Δηώ Nonn. D. 30.68.
Nic. Th. 113.
SIG 1185 ( Tanagra), IG 7.2426 ( Thebes).

definition: ἁλώμεναι, Ep. for ἁλῶναι, v. sub ἁλίσκομαι.

children.definition: Thphr. Sign. 31 (pl., in sense ΙΙ.1), LXX Ho. 9.2, BGU 651.5 (ii A.D.); more freq. in oblique cases, BCH 39.55 (Arcad., iv B.C., in sense of plantation (?)), PLille 13.3, Arist. Vent. 973a14, LXX Ge. 50.10, etc.
work on a threshing-floor, App. Mac. 13.
contractor for salt-works, Inscr.Prien. 111.
bought with salt, ἁ. δουλάρια worthless slaves from Thrace, because Thracians sold men for salt, Zen. 2.12.
threshing-floor, Ath. 12.524a, CPR 73.20 (ii A.D.), Sch. Nic. Th. 541:—written ἁλωνεία, ἡ, Sch. Il. 5.499, BGU 663 (iii A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: grain on threshing-floor, PRyl. 442.4 (iii A.D.), POxy. 1107.3 (v/vi A.D.).

children.label: III
children.definition: Nic. Th. 166.
for a threshing-floor, ὑποζύγια prob. in PStrassb. 93.5 (ii B. C.); κόσκινον Edict.Diocl. 15.56.

definition: ἁλώνιον, τό, Dim. of ἅλων, Gp. 12.2.2, Hdn.Gr. 2.763, Gloss.

children.definition: shaped like a threshing-floor, χώρα Hero *Mens. 56.
Suid. S.V. ἁλωνία.

children.label: II
children.definition: beat on a threshing-floor, Longus 3.29.
office of guard of a threshing-floor, PRyl. 90.39 (iii A.D.).
guard of a threshing-floor, POxy. 1465.8 (i B.C.).
grown in a vineyard, οἶνος Nonn. D. 13.267.

definition: ἀλωπέκειος, α, ον, Ion. ἀλωπέκ-εος, η, ον,

children.definition: of a fox, στέαρ Gal. 14.331; λίπος Philum. ap. Orib. 45.29.36.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀλωπεκέη, Att. contr. -κῆ (sc. δορά), fox-skin, Hdt. 7.75: prov., ὅπου ἡ λεοντῆ μὴ ἐφικνεῖται, προσραπτέον ἐκεῖ τὴν ἀλωπεκῆν Plu. Lys. 7.

data.quote: ὅπου ἡ λεοντῆ μὴ ἐφικνεῖται, προσραπτέον ἐκεῖ τὴν ἀλωπεκῆν

children.definition: Hsch.; cf. ἀλωπεκίς III.
mange in foxes, in which hair falls off, dub. in S. Fr. 419, cf. Gal. 12.381: pl., bald patches on the head, Arist. Pr. 893b38.

children.label: II
children.definition: fox-earth, Hsch., EM 75.6.
branded with a fox, Luc. Pisc. 47.

children.label: II
children.definition: thresher shark, Lat. Squalus vulpes, Arist. Fr. 310, Mnesim. 4.49, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 8.356c.
fox-cub, Ar. Pax 1067, Ael. NA 7.47.
Epic.Alex.Adesp. 2.9.
play the fox, οὐκ ἔστιν ἀλωπεκίζειν Ar. V. 1241; ἄλλοις ἀλωπέκιζε τοῖς ἀπειρήτοις Babr. 95.64: prov., ἀ. πρὸς ἑτέραν ἀλώπεκα ‘Greek meets Greek’, Zen. 1.70.

children.label: II
children.definition: overreach, Hsch.
Dim. of ἀλώπηξ, little fox, Ar. Eq. 1076, 1079.
mongrel between fox and dog, = κυναλώπηξ, X. Cyn. 3.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: fox-skin cap, X. An. 7.4.4.

children.label: III
children.definition: grape, so-called from its colour, Plin. HN 14.42.
like fox, Gal. 4.604.
beard-grass, Polypogon monspeliensis, Thphr. HP 7.11.2.
fox-like, sly, Hsch., EM 75.5.

definition: ἀλωπεύει (cod. ἀλοπ-) · ἀνιχνεύει, Hsch.; cf. ἀλωπός.
ἀλώπηξ [ᾰ], εκος (also ἀλώπηκος Anan. 5), ἡ; dat. pl., ἀλώπεξι LXX 3 Ki. 21.10, Ep. ἀλωπήκεσσι Opp. C. 1.433:—

children.definition: fox, Canis vulpes (smaller Egyptian species Arist. HA 606a24, C. niloticus), Archil. 86.2, 89.5, Semon. 7.7, Hdt. 2.67, etc.: of sly persons, ἀλώπεκος ἴχνεσι βαίνειν Sol. 11.5; μῆτιν ἀ. a very fox for craft, Pi. I. 4(3).65: prov., τὴν . . Ἀρχιλόχου ἀλώπεκα ἑλκτέον ἐξόπισθεν we must trail Archilochus’ fox-skin behind, i.e. deceive by false appearances, Pl. R. 365c; πολλῆς αὐτῆς τῆς ἀ. ἐπιχέαντες Eun. Hist. p.249D.; ἡ ἀ. τὸν βοῦν ἐλαύνει ‘sleight masters might’, Diogenian. 2.73; πεινῶσαν ἀ. ὕπνος ἐπέρχεται ‘qui dort dine’, Id. 7.91; ἡ κέρκος τῇ ἀλώπεκι μαρτυρεῖ ‘ex pede Herculem’, Id. 5.15; ἀλλʼ οὐκ αὖθις ἀ. (sc. πάγαις ἁλώσεται) ‘a burnt child dreads the fire’, Id. 2.15.

children.label: II
children.definition: bat, Sciurus or Pteromys volans, Arist. HA 490a7.

children.label: IV
children.definition: muscles of the loins, psoas-muscles, Clearch. 92, Ruf. Onom. 189.

children.label: V
children.definition: mange, Herod. 7.72, Call. Dian. 79: in pl., bald patches, Hp. Aff. 35.

children.label: VI
children.definition: dance, dub. in S. Fr. 419 (prob. in sense v), cf. Hsch. s.v. ὄρχησις.
Hdn.Gr. 1.189:—fem. ἀλωπά, ἡ, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., = ἀλωπεκώδης, S. Fr. 263.
fox-coloured, f.l. for ἀλφιτόχρους, AB 381, Eust. 1968.39.
watchers of salt, Suid., EM 74.28.

definition: ἅλως [ᾰ], ἡ, gen. ἅλω Hp. VM 13, X. Oec. 18.8, ἅλωος AP 6.258 (Adaeus); dat. ἅλῳ Arist. Ph. 198b22; acc. ἅλω A. Th. 489, IG 2.834b ii 21, ἅλων Nic. Th. 166, ἅλωα Call. Fr. 51: pl., nom. ἅλῳ Arist. Mete. 344b2, ἅλωες Ach.Tat. Intr.Arat. 32, ἅλως D. 42.6, Thphr. Sign. 22; acc. ἅλως Arist. Mir. 835b9, etc.: (v. sub ἀλέω A):—

children.definition: threshing-floor, Hp. l.c., X. l.c., etc.; grain on the floor, PRyl. 122.10 (ii A.D.):—hence, from round shape,

children.label: II
children.definition: disk of sun or moon, or shield, A. l.c.: later, halo, Arist. Mete. 344b2, Epicur. Ep. 2p.51U., Gal. 5.640, etc.
serpentʼs coil, Nic. Th. 166.
birdʼs nest, Ael. NA 3.16.
ciliary body of the eye, Poll. 2.71.
circular piazza at Delphi, GDI 2101, 2642.
easy to take or conquer, of places and persons, Hdt. 3.153, E. Hel. 1622, Th. 4.9: metaph., easily beguiled, X. Mem. 3.11.11.
easy to apprehend, S. Ph. 863 (lyr.).
capable of solution, ἀπόκρισις Aristid. 2.275J.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἅλωσις) of or belonging to capture or conquest, παιὰν ἁ. song of triumph on taking city, A. Th. 635; βάξις ἁ. tidings of capture, Ag. 10.
capture, Pi. O. 10(11).42, Hdt. 1.5, 3.156, A. Ag. 589, etc.; δαΐων ἅ. conquest by enemy, Id. Th. 119: means of conquest, S. Ph. 61.
taking, catching of birds and fish, Arist. HA 593a20, 600a3 (pl.); ἑαλωκότες ἰσχυρὰν ἅλωσιν taken without power to escape, Plu. Num. 15.

children.label: II
children.definition: conviction, Pl. Lg. 920a, D.C. Fr. 97.3.

definition: Ἁλώτια, τά, festival at Tegea, Paus. 8.47.4.

children.definition: liable to capture or conquest, Th. 6.77, Philostr. Im. 1.4; ἡδονῇ ἁλωτὸν ἄνθρωπος Ph. 2.381.
captured, Philostr. VA 2.10.

children.label: II
children.definition: attainable, S. OT 111, Men. 132.
unremitting, Plu. Fab. 23, QPlat. 2.1005e, AP 5.255.12 ( Paul.Sil.), Nonn. D. 13.267, etc.

definition: ἄμ, for ἀνά, before words beginning with β, π, φ, μ, e.g. ἂμ βωμοῖσι, ἂμ μέσον, ἂμ πεδίον, ἂμ πέλαγος, ἂμ φυτά; also compds., as ἀμπαύω:—mostly Dor., as in Pi., but also in Hom., sts. in Trag.
ἅμα [ᾰμ], Dor. ἁμᾶ, q.v.: (v. sub fin.):

children.label: A
children.definition: Adv. at once, at the same time, mostly of Time, freq. added to τε . . καί, ἅμʼ οἰμωγή τε καὶ εὐχωλή Il. 8.64; ἅ. τʼ ὠκύμορος καὶ ὀϊζυρός 1.417; σέ θʼ ἅ. κλαίω καὶ ἐμέ 24.773; σαυτόν θʼ ἅ. κἀμέ S. Ph. 772, cf. 119; ἄνους τε καὶ γέρων ἅ. Ant. 281:—with καί only, ἅ. πρόσσω καὶ ὀπίσσω Il. 3.109; with τε . . τε, χειρῶν τε βίης θʼ ἅ. ἔργον ἔφαινον Hes. Th. 677.

data.quote: τε . . καί, ἅμʼ οἰμωγή τε καὶ εὐχωλή
σέ θʼ ἅ. κλαίω καὶ ἐμέ
τε . . τε, χειρῶν τε βίης θʼ ἅ. ἔργον ἔφαινον

children.definition: ἅ. μέν . . ἅ. δέ . . , partly . . partly . . , Pl. Phd. 115d, X. HG 3.1.3:— ἅ. τε . . καὶ ἅ. Pl. Grg. 497a; ἅμʼ ἡδέως ἔμοιγε κἀλγεινῶς ἅμα S. Ant. 436.

ἅ. δέ . . καί . . , ἅ. τε . . καί . . , ἅ. . . καί . . may often be translated by no sooner . . than . . , ἅ. δὲ ταῦτα ἔλεγε καὶ ἀπεδείκνυε Hdt. 1.112; ταῦγά τε ἅμα ἠγόρευε καὶ πέμπει 8.5; ἅ. ἀκηκόαμέν τε καὶ τριηράρχους καθίσταμεν D. 4.36; ἅ. διαλλάττονται καὶ τῆς ἔχθρας ἐπιλανθάνονται Isoc. 4.157.

data.quote: ἅ. δὲ ταῦτα ἔλεγε καὶ ἀπεδείκνυε
ταῦγά τε ἅμα ἠγόρευε καὶ πέμπει
ἅ. ἀκηκόαμέν τε καὶ τριηράρχους καθίσταμεν
ἅ. διαλλάττονται καὶ τῆς ἔχθρας ἐπιλανθάνονται

children.label: b
children.definition: ἅ. μῦθος ἔην, τετέλεστο δὲ ἔργον ‘no sooner said than done’, Il. 19.242; ἅ. ἔπος τε καὶ ἔργον ἐμήδετο h.Merc. 46; ταῦτα εἶπε καὶ ἅ. ἔπος τε καὶ ἔργον ἐποίεε Hdt. 3.134, cf. 9.92: prov., ἅμʼ ἔπος ἅμʼ ἔργον Diogenian. 1.36.

data.quote: ἅ. ἔπος τε καὶ ἔργον ἐμήδετο
ταῦτα εἶπε καὶ ἅ. ἔπος τε καὶ ἔργον ἐποίεε

children.label: c
children.definition: part. and finite Verb in same sense, βρίζων ἅ. . . ἐξήμελξας εὐτραφὲς γάλα A. Ch. 897; ἅ. εἰπὼν ἀνέστη as soon as he had done speaking, he stood up, X. An. 3.1.47; τῆς ἀγγελίας ἅ. ῥηθείσης ἐπεβοήθουν as soon as news was brought they assisted, Th. 2.5; ἅ. γιγνόμενοι λαμβάνομεν Pl. Phd. 76c; ἡμῖν ἅ. ἀναπαυομένοις ὁ παῖς ἀναγνώσεται Tht. 143b.

data.quote: ἡμῖν ἅ. ἀναπαυομένοις ὁ παῖς ἀναγνώσεται

children.definition: ἅ. μέν . . ἔτι δέ . . X. Cyr. 1.4.3; ἅ. μέν . . πρὸς δέ . . Hdt. 8.51.

children.label: II
children.definition: together, at once, both, without direct ref. to time, ἅ. πάντες or πάντες ἅ. Il. 1.495, al.; ἅ. ἄμφω h.Cer. 15; ἅ. κρατερὸς καὶ ἀμύμων Od. 3.111, etc.: of Place, Arist. Metaph. 1028b27.

children.label: III
children.definition: σύν or μετά, E. Ion 717, Pl. Criti. 110a.

children.label: IV
children.definition: at one and the same time, αἱ πᾶσαι [νῆες] ἅ. ἐγίγνοντο ἐν ἑνὶ θέρει σʹ καὶ νʹ (250) Th. 3.17, cf. οὐχ ἅ. ἡ κτῆσις παραγίγνεται D. 23.113.

data.quote: αἱ πᾶσαι [νῆες] ἅ. ἐγίγνοντο ἐν ἑνὶ θέρει σʹ καὶ νʹ (250)

children.label: B
children.definition: part. added), at the same time with, together with, ἅμʼ ἠοῖ φαινομένηφι at dawn, Il. 9.682, al.; ἅ. ἕῳ, ἅ. ἕῳ γιγνομένῃ, Th. 1.48, 4.32; ἅμʼ ἠελίῳ ἀνιόντι or καταδύντι at sunrise or sunset, Il. 18.136, 210, al.; ἅμʼ ἡμέρῃ διαφωσκούσῃ Hdt. 3.86, al.; ἅμʼ ἡμέρᾳ E. El. 78, Th. 2.94, etc., Att.; ἅμʼ ἦρι ἀρχομένῳ or ἅ. ἦρι at beginning of spring, Th. 5.20, 2.2, etc.; ἅ. κήδεϊ κεκάρθαι τὰς κεφαλάς during the time of . . , Hdt. 2.36; ἅ. τειχισμῷ Th. 7.20; ἅμα τῷ διαυγάζειν Plb. 3.104.5 (without Art. ἅμα εὑρεθῆναι Ps.-Plu. Fluv. 23.2).

together with, ἅ. τινὶ στείχειν Il. 16.257; ὀπάσσαι 24.461, al.; Ἑλένην καὶ κτήμαθʼ ἅμʼ αὐτῇ 3.458; ἅ. πνοιῇς ἀνέμοιο keeping pace with the wind, Od. 1.98; repeated, ἅμʼ αὐτῷ . . ἅμʼ ἕποντο 11.371; οἱ ἅ. Θόαντι Hdt. 6.138, cf. Th. 7.57.

children.label: II
children.definition: Herod. 4.95, POxy. 903 (iv A. D.), Pythag. Sim. 28, Olymp.Hist. p.453 D.; dub. in Thphr. Char. 6.9.

children.label: C
children.definition: as soon as, ἅ. ἂν ἡβήσῃ τις τῶν ὀρφανῶν Pl. Lg. 928c, cf. Lex ap. D. 46.20; ἅ. κα διεξέλθῃ ὁ χρόνος GDI 2160 ( Delph., ii B. C.). (Root sṃ-, cf. A α 11.)

data.quote: ἅ. ἂν ἡβήσῃ τις τῶν ὀρφανῶν

children.definition: Dor. for ἅμα, Pi. O. 3.21, IG 5(1), Ar. Lys. 1318, Call. Lav.Pall. 75, Theoc. 9.4. ( ἁμᾷ Hdn.Gr. 1.489; ἅμᾳ Thphr. Metaph. 6, al. (cod. opt.).)
fig, Cretan, Hermonax. ap. Ath. 3.76f.
Theognost. Can. 163.22; in form ἁμάδιος, Et.Gen.
Pl. Epigr. 26.6 Diehl, Pherenicus ap. Ath. 3.78b: sg., Ἁμαδρυάς A.R. 2.477, Ant.Lib. 30.4.
battle with Amazons, Sch. Il. 2.219.
the Amazons, Il. 3.189, etc.; ὁ τῶν Ἀ. τροχίσκος, a famous remedy, Asclep. ap. Gal. 12.152, etc.:—also Ἀμαζονίδες, αἱ, Pi. O. 13.87, Call. Dian. 237.

children.label: II
children.definition: Paus. 4.31.8:— Adj. Ἀμαζ-ονικός, ή, όν, Plu. Pomp. 35, Paus. 1.41.7:— -κά, τά, title of Epic by Onasus, Sch. A.R. 1.1236, Sch. Theoc. 13.46:—also Ἀμαζ-όνιος, ον, Nonn. D. 37.17; epith. of Apollo in Laconia, Paus. 3.25.3. (Commonly derived from μαζός, from the fable that they got rid of the right breast, that it might not interfere with the use of the bow.)

children.label: III
children.definition: ἀ- priv., μᾶζα) poor, starveling, ἄνδρες Call. Fr. 523.
to be untaught, ignorant, only pres.; abs., Pl. R. 535e, Ph. 1.498, Aristid. 34(50).44, Plot. 4.4.24; ἀ. τι or εἴς τι to be ignorant in a thing, Pl. Lg. 689c, 689d.

definition: ἀμαθεῖν θερίζειν, Hsch. ἀμαθηίς, suggested for ψαμαθηίς (v. ἄμαθος) by Sch. Nic. Th. 887.

children.definition: ignorant, stupid, Hdt. 1.33, Democr. 169, etc.; ἔθνεα ἀμαθέστατα Hdt. 4.46; ἀνὴρ πένης, εἰ καὶ γένοιτο μὴ ἀ. E. Supp. 421, al., Ar. Nu. 135; ἀ. καὶ βδελυρός Id. Eq. 193; ἀμαθεστάτους πάντων ἀνθρώπων And. 2.2; ἀ. τὴν [ἐκείνων] ἀμαθίαν Pl. Ap. 22e; opp. δεξιός, Th. 3.82; of animals, such as wild boars, unmanageable, θυμώδη καὶ ἀ. Arist. HA 488b14: c. gen. rei, without knowledge of a thing, unlearned in it, -έστερος τοῦ καλοῦ E. Or. 417; λῃστείας Th. 4.41, cf. 3.37; ἀ. περί τινος Pl. Erx. 394e; τι La. 194d; πρός τι Lg. 679d. Adv. -θῶς ignorantly, through ignorance, ἥμαρτον E. Ph. 874: Comp. -έστερον, τῶν νόμων ὑπεροψίας παιδεύεσθαι to be educated with too little learning to despise the laws, Th. 1.84; -έστερόν πως εἰπὲ καὶ σαφέστερον less learnedly, Ar. Ra. 1445.

data.quote: ἀνὴρ πένης, εἰ καὶ γένοιτο μὴ ἀ.

children.label: b
children.definition: unfeeling, inhuman, ἀ. τις εἶ θεός E. HF 347.
ἀ. παρρησία boorish freedom of speech, E. Or. 905; ἀ. ῥώμη brute force, Id. Fr. 732; ἀ. δύναμις Plu. Demetr. 42; ἀ. φρόνημα barbarous pride, E. Heracl. 459.

children.label: II
children.definition: not heard of, unknown, ἀ. ἔρρει E. Ion 916. Adv. ἀμαθῶς, χωρῆσαι, of events, to take an unforeseen course, Th. 1.140.
Phryn.Com. 8; ἀ. γραμμάτων Procop. Arc. 6.
ignorance, stupidity, Heraclit. 95, 109, Hp. Art. 67 (v.l. -είην), S. Fr. 924, E. Ph. 584, etc.; opp. δεξιότης, Th. 3.37; ἀ. τινός Democr. 83, X. Mem. 4.2.22; περὶ τὰ μέγιστα Pl. Lg. 688c.
boorishness, lack of culture, X. Ath. 1.5, E. Cyc. 173, Isoc. 15.248.
wilful blindness, sin, IG 4.951.39 (Epid.), cf. E. Ba. 490.
discourtesy, Id. Med. 224; perversity, Id. HF 1254.
dwelling in sand, ἀ. κόγχοι sand-snails, Epich. 42.

definition: ἄμαθος [ ᾰμ], ἡ, Ep. form of ἄμμος,

senses.definition: sand, Il. 5.587, A.R. 4.1239, etc.: pl., links, dunes by the sea, h.Ap. 439; generally, sandy soil, Nic. Th. 262. (Dist. by Gramm., e.g. Sch. Il. 9.384, from ψάμμος (q.v.) as dust from sea-sand, but prob. wrongly:— ἄμ- is for ἅμ-, i. e. σάμ-, cf. sand.)

definition: ἀμαθύνω, ( ἄμαθος) Ep., only pres., impf., and (in Q.S. 14.645) aor.:—

children.definition: level with the dust, utterly destroy, πόλιν Il. 9.593; [ ἄνδρα] μέγα φωνοῦντα A. Eu. 937 (lyr.); ἀ. ἐν φλογὶ σάρκα Theoc. 2.26:— Pass., Q.S. 2.334.
scatter like sand, h.Merc. 140.
sandy, ποταμός Str. 8.3.14.
not yet delivered, Nonn. D. 1.5; γαστήρ 41.133.

children.label: II
children.definition: without aid of midwife, λοχείη Opp. C. 1.40.

definition: ἀμαιμάκετος, η, ον, also ος, ον Hes. Sc. 207:—

children.definition: irresistible, old Ep. word, also in Lyr. and Trag. (lyr.); of Chimaera, Il. 6.179, 16.329; of fire vomited by her, Hes. Th. 319; of fire generally, S. OT 177; θάλασσα, πόντος, Hes. Sc. 207, Pi. P. 1.14; of shipʼs mast, proof against any strain, Od. 14.311; of the trident, Pi. I. 8(7).37; ἀ. μένος, κινηθμός, P. 3.33, 4.208; νεῖκος stubborn, B. 10.64; of the Furies, S. OC 127; ἀ. βυθοῖς in unfathomable depths, IG 3.900. [Usu. derived fr. ἀ- intens., μαιμάω, i.e. furious; but apptly. connected with ἄμαχος by Poets.]
ἅπαξ (Cret.), Hsch. ( -κι- = -qui-, cf. ἀμάτις, πολλάκις).

definition: ἄμαλα τὴν ναῦν ἀπὸ τοῦ ἀμᾶν τὴν ἅλα, Hsch. ( A. Fr. 214); ἁμάδα· τὴν ναῦν, EM 75.22: hence ἐπʼ ἄμαλα restored by Herm., A. Supp. 842, 847, where ἐπαμίδα cod. Med.
ἀμαλακία, ἡ, v.l. for sq., Lyd. Mens. 4.71.

children.definition: incapability of being softened, hardness, etym. of Ἀμάλθεια, D.S. 4.35.
that cannot be softened, intractable, of materials, Arist. Mete. 385a13; ἄτηκτα καὶ ἀ. 388b25.
unmitigated, τὸ ψυχρόν Plu. Frig. 2.953e: metaph. of expression, harsh, Longin. 15.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: unfeeling, Sch. S. Aj. 776.
destroy, efface, aor. ἠμάλαψα S. Fr. 465, Lyc. 34:— Pass., ἀμαλαπτομέναν prob. in A. Pr. 899 (Weil).

definition: ἀμαλδύνω, ( ἀμαλός) Ep. (not in Od.) and Ion. word, properly,

children.definition: soften, mitigate, ἐλπωρὴ ἀμαλδύνει κακότητα Q.S. 1.73, cf. 13.401; but in early Ep. crush, destroy, τεῖχος ἀμαλδῦναι Il. 12.18; bring low, συμφορὰ ἐσθλὸν ἀμαλδύνει B. 13.3; put an end to, τὴν διὰ τοῦ ὀμφαλοῦ πνοήν Hp. Nat.Puer. 17; use up, squander, χρήματα Theoc. 16.59; weaken, ὀφθαλμούς Cat.Cod.Astr. 2.174:— Pass., ὥς κεν . . τεῖχος ἀμαλδύνηται Il. 7.463; ἀμαλδυνθήσομαι Ar. Pax 380; ὄμματα ἀ. Hp. Mul. 2.201; ἀ. ἡ δίοδος τῆς γονῆς Id. Genit. 2; ἀμαλδυνθεῖσα χρόνῳ περικαλλέα μορφήν AP 6.18 ( Jul.); neglect, waste, Democr. 202.
conceal, disguise, εἶδος h.Cer. 94, cf. A.R. 1.834; efface, στίβον Id. 4.112.
Semus 19, Philostr.Jun. Im. 10.
reaper, Opp. C. 1.522.
unmitigated, Aret. CA 2.11; inexorable, φρένες AP 5.233 ( Paul.Sil.); ἐπιθυμία Olymp. in Alc. p.66C.

definition: Ἀμάλθεια, Ion. Ἀμαλθ-είη or Ἀμαλθ-ῐη, ἡ,

children.definition: Amaltheia, which suckled Zeus, Call. Fr. 49: from her horn flowed whatever its possessor wished, hence κέρας Ἀμαλθείας horn of plenty, Anacr. 8, Phoc. 7, Ar. Fr. 39 D.; applied to parks, etc., Duris 41, D.S. 3.68, etc.; title of book, Gell. Praef. 6:—also Ἀμαλθ-εῖον, τό, country-house of Atticus in Epirus, Cic. Att. 1.16, cf. 18.
S. Fr. 95; cf. foreg.

definition: Ἀμάλιος, ὁ, sc. μήν, month at Delphi, GDI 1694, al.

children.definition: bundle of ears of corn, sheaf, S. Fr. 607, Plu. Publ. 8.
sheaf-band, Call.Com. 3 D.
bind into sheaves or bundles, EM 76.6.
Hsch., Eust. 1162.29.
binder of sheaves, Il. 18.553, Aret. SD 2.13.

definition: ἀμαλλοδέτης, ου, ὁ, = foreg., Theoc. 10.44, AP 10.16 ( Theaet.).

children.definition: without fleece or nap, Eust. 1057.12.

definition: ἄμαλλος (B): πέρδιξ ( Polyrrhenian), Hsch.:—also ἄμαλλοι· φυτὰ σικύων ἢ τῶν ὁμοίων, Id.

children.definition: producer of sheaves, Jo.Gaz. 2.31; pecul. fem. of, ἀμαλλο-τόκος, ον, sheaf-producing, Nonn. D. 7.84; πεδία Hymn.Is. 3.
bringing sheaves, Euph. 103, Porph. Abst. 2.19; of Demeter, Nonn. D. 17.153, Eust. 1162.27; cf. ἁμιλλοφόρος.
effutat, Gloss.
Alciphr. 2.3.

soft, weak, in Hom. of young animals, Il. 22.310, Od. 20.14; γέρων E. Heracl. 75; παῖς Call. Fr. 49 P.: irreg. Comp. -έστερος, ὄψις -εστέρα Adam. 2.2. (Perh. cognate with Skt. mṛdús ‘soft’, Lat. mollis.)

definition: Ἀμαλώιος, ὁ, sc. μήν, month at Cyme in Aeolis, BCH 12.362.

children.definition: ὁμοίως), v.l. in Hp. Morb. 1.8, 2.8, Int. 30, cf. Gal. 19.76.

definition: ἁμάμαξυς [ ᾰμᾰ], ἡ, gen. υος or (in Sapph.) υδος,

children.definition: vine trained on two poles, Epich. 24, Sapph. 150, Matro Conv. 114.
medlar, Mespilus germanica, Hp. Mul. 1.44, Aristomen. 11, cf. Ath. 14.650c.
mince-meat, Phot.p.86R. ἀμαμίξαι· ἀποπνῖξαι, Hsch. (Cf. ἀμαλίζω, ἀμμιάξαι.) ἀμάναν· ἅμαξαν, Id. ἀμανδαλοῖ· ἀφανίζει, Id. ἀμάνδᾰλος, = ἀφανής, as if ἀμάλδανος fr. ἀμαλδύνω, Alc. 123.
‘champignons’, a kind of fungus, Nic. Fr. 79, Gal. 6.656, Eust. 290.3, etc. ἀμάνορες· δοθιῆνες ( Elean), Hsch.
not to be foretold or conjectured, τύχη Max.Tyr. 11.6.
lacking in oracles, Philostr. Im. 1.4.
Act., not divining, τοῦ μέλλοντος Charito 2.2: hence, of dogs with bad noses, Poll. 5.63. ἄμαντις, ι, not divining, ἄ. μαντική Oenom. ap. Eus. PE 5.21.

definition: ἄμαξα [ᾰ], Att. ἅμαξα, ἡ, (v. ἄξων) prop.

children.definition: frame-work, ‘châssis’ of a four-wheeled wagon ( ἀπήνη), opp. πείρινς (body), Il. 24.263 sqq., cf. Od. 6.37, al.:—also, of the whole wagon, ib. 260, cf. Hes. Op. 453, Hdt. 1.31, Th. 1.93, etc.; of the wagons of the Scythians, Hdt. 4.114, 121; βοῦς ὑφʼ ἁμάξης draught-oxen, X. An. 6.4.22, 25.
wagon-load, πετρῶν, σίτου, X. An. 4.7.10, Cyr. 2.4.18; ἐλλεβόρου Pl. Euthd. 299b; τρισσῶν ἁμαξῶν βάρος E. Cyc. 385, cf. 473.

ἡ ἅμαξα τὸν βοῦν (sc. ἕλκει) ‘the cart before the horse’, Luc. DMort. 16[6].2; ἐξ ἁμάξης ὑβρίζειν, of abusive ribaldry, such as was allowed to the women as they were taken in wagons to the Eleusinian mysteries, Sch. D. 18.122, cf. Ar. Pl. 1014, Men. 396; βοᾶς . . ὥσπερ ἐξ ἁμάξης D. l.c.

children.label: II
children.definition: carriage of a plough, Hes. Op. 426, 453.

children.label: III
children.definition: the Great Bear, Il. 18.487, Od. 5.273, Call. Iamb. 1.119, etc.

children.label: IV
children.definition: ship, A. Fr. 451B.

children.label: V
children.definition: AP 7.479 ( Theodorid.).
of or like a wagon, ἁ. ἄρκτος (cf. ἄμαξα III), Arat. 93, cf. Nonn. D. 1.251.
official of the imperial transport service, BCH 33.67 (Caesarea Cappad.).
loading of wagons, Suid.; haulage (in form -ήα), IG 4.823 ( Troezen).
wagoner, D.Chr. 64.23: βοῦς ἁ. draught-ox, Plu. Dio 38, Philostr. Gym. 43.
traverse with a wagon:— Pass., to be traversed by wagon-roads, of country, Hdt. 2.108.
ἁ. βίοτον drag on a weary life, AP 9.574.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be a wagoner, Plu. Eum. 1; travel in a wagon, AP 7.478 ( Leon.); live in wagons, of Scythians, Philostr. VA 7.26.
axle-pins, Sch. E. Hipp. 1235.
drive a wagon, Hsch. s.v. ἀμπρεύειν.
wagoner, Ostr.Strassb. 671 (iiA.D.): written ἁμαξ-ολάτης ib. 738.
traversed by wagons: ἡ ἁ. (sc. ὁδός) carriage-road, Aen.Tact. 16.14, Poll. 9.37, cf. Str. 6.3.7.
axle-blocks, Poll. 1.253, cf. Ath.Mech. 16.9: sg., -ήπους IG 2.834c.
of or on a carriage, θρόνος, = δίφρος, A. Ag. 1054; τρίβος high-road, E. Or. 1251.

large enough to load a wagon, λίθος X. HG 2.4.27, Arist. Mir. 838b1, D. 55.20, Diph. 38, cf. IG 2(2).463.45, Ἐφ.Ἀρχ. 1895.59: metaph., ἁ. ῥῆμα of big words, Com.Adesp. 836; ἁ. χρήματα money in cart-loads, ib. 835.
for wagon, Thphr. HP 5.7.6.

definition: ἁμάξιον, τό, = sq., Arist. MA 701b4, Plu. Dio 9.

children.definition: Dim. of ἅμαξα, little wagon, Hdt. 3.113; go-cart, as childʼs toy, or cake of that shape, Ar. Nu. 864.
Hsch.
of or for wagon, φόρτος AP 9.306 ( Antiphil.).

definition: ἁμαξιτός, ον, Ep. and Lyr. ἀμ-, ( ἅμαξα, εἶμι ibo)

children.definition: traversed by wagons, ἁ. ὁδός carriage-road, high-road, highway, Pi. N. 6.54, X. An. 1.2.21; without ὁδός, as Subst., Il. 22.146, h.Cer. 177, Thgn. 599, Hdt. 7.200, IG 4.926 (Epid.), Tab.Heracl. 1.60; ἐν τριπλαῖς ἁ. in a place where three ways meet, S. OT 716, etc.
πειθοῦς ἁ. Emp. 133; μακρά μοι νεῖσθαι κατʼ ἀμαξιτόν Pi. P. 4.247.
living in wagons, as nomad tribes do, Porph. Abst. 3.15.
like a wagon, Eust. 1156.15.
dwelling in a wagon, Str. 7.3.2, 11.2.1.
down-roller ( i.e. destroyer) of wagons: in pl., name of a Megarian family, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.304e.
build wagons, Nic.Dam.p.28D., Poll. 7.115.
wagon-building, Thphr. HP 5.7.6.
cartwright, PLond.ined. 2383 A (ii B. C.), Plu. Per. 12.
large enough to fill a wagon, λᾶας E. Ph. 1158; λίθος Aen.Tact. 32.5; ὄστρεια Luc. VH 1.41.
Heraclid. Pol. 36.
track of a wain or car, Call.Com. 10.
Thphr. HP 3.10.1.
cartwrights’ slang, Ar. Eq. 464.
carried in wagons, οἶκος, of the Scythians, Pi. Fr. 104.

definition: ἆμαρ, ατος, τό, Dor. for ἦμαρ.

children.definition: trench, conduit, channel, for watering meadows, χερσὶ μάκελλαν ἔχων, ἀμάρης ἐξ ἔχματα βάλλων Il. 21.259; κρηναῖαι ἀμάραι A.R. 3.1392; βάλλεις εἰς ἀμάραν με Theoc. 27.53, cf. Sapph. 151, Call. Cer. 30, PFlor. 50.106.

data.quote: χερσὶ μάκελλαν ἔχων, ἀμάρης ἐξ ἔχματα βάλλων

children.definition: hollow of ear, EM 77.23 (pl.).
made of amaracus, μύρον Antiph. 106; ἔλαιον Edict.Diocl.Delph. 16.

definition: ἀμάρακον [ ᾰμᾱ], τό, and ἀμάρᾰκος, ὁ,

children.definition: marjoram, Origanum Majorana, Pherecr. 131.3 (gender uncertain); masc. in Chaerem. 14.16; Thphr. has both, HP 6.1.1 ( -ος), 1.9.4 ( -ον), cf. Nic. Th. 575, APl. 16.188 (Nicias).
of amaranth, i.e. unfading, στέφανος Philostr. Her. 19.14.
unfading, imperishable, στέφανος 1 Ep.Pet. 5.4.
unfading, λειμών Luc. Dom. 9: metaph., σοφία LXX Wi. 6.12; κληρονομία 1 Ep.Pet. 1.4, cf. CIG 2942c ( Tralles); πνεῦμα prob. in IPE 2.286 ( Panticapaeum): neut. pl. as Adv., Philostr. Im. 1.9.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. ἀμάραντον, τό (but in Lat. amarantus), never-fading flower, IG 14.607e ( Carales), Poll. 1.229; = ἑλίχρυσον, Dsc. 4.57; = κενταύρειον μικρόν, Ps.- Dsc. 3.7; = χρυσοκόμη. Id. 4.55.

definition: ἀμαράσαι αἱ σῦς, οἱ δὲ κύνες, Hsch.; cf. μαράσαι.

children.definition: Hsch. s.v. ἄβαρτος.
foul water carried off by drain ( ἀθροίσματα βορβόρου), Hsch.
flow off, Aristaenet. 1.17.
from a conduit, ὕδωρ Nonn. D. 47.183.
digger of trenches, Man. 4.252.
gout in all limbs at once, Cael.Aur. TP 5.2.

SIG 490 (Orchomenus in Arcadia, iii B. C.), cf. Sammelb. 357 ( Egypt): — Ἀμάριον, τό, precinct at Aegium in which the Achaean League met, prob. l. in Str. 8.7.3 and 5 (but Ὁμάριον Plb. 5.93.10, hence Ἀμάριος prob. = Ὁμάριος, Ὁμαγύριος (cf. ἀμαρεῖν, ἁμαρτῆ), and is not connected with ἀμάρα = ἡμέρα).

definition: ἁμαρτάνω [ ᾰμ . . ᾰν]: fut. ἁμαρτήσομαι Od. 9.512, Th. 4.55, etc.; later -ήσω Ev.Matt. 18.21, D.C. 59.20, Gal. 7.653, ( δι-) Hp. Praec. 9, ( ἐξ-) Id. Acut. (Sp.)7 [was: 13]: aor. 2 ἥμαρτον Thgn., Pi., Att.; Ep. ἤμβροτον, but only ind.; Aeol. 3 sg. ἄμβροτε Sapph. Supp. 1.5, inf. ἀμβρότην IG 12(2).1.15 ( Mytilene); opt. ἁμάρτοιν (for ἁμάρτοιμι) Cratin. 55 (dub.): aor. 1 ἡμάρτησα Emp. 115.4 (dub.), AP 7.339 ( Pall. or Luc.), D.S. 2.14: pf. ἡμάρτηκα Hdt. 9.79, Ar. Pl. 961, etc., Att.:— Pass., aor. ἡμαρτήθην Th. 2.65, X. Vect. 4.37: pf. ἡμάρτημαι S. OC 439, Antipho 5.77, etc.: plpf. ἡμάρτητο Th. 7.18, Lys. 31.20:—

children.definition: miss the mark, esp. of spear thrown, abs., Il. 5.287, etc.; ἔρριψεν, οὐδʼ ἥμαρτε A. Fr. 80: c. gen., φωτὸς ἁ. Il. 10.372; also τῶν μεγάλων ψυχῶν ἱεὶς οὐκ ἂν ἁμάρτοις S. Aj. 155; ἁ. τῆς ὁδοῦ miss road, Ar. Pl. 961; τοῦ σκοποῦ Antipho 3.4.5.

data.quote: τῶν μεγάλων ψυχῶν ἱεὶς οὐκ ἂν ἁμάρτοις

children.definition: fail of oneʼs purpose, go wrong, abs., Od. 21.155, A. Ag. 1194, etc.: c. gen., οὔ τι νοήματος ἤμβροτεν ἐσθλοῦ Od. 7.292; μύθων ἡμάρτανε failed of good speech, 11.511; γνώμης, ἐλπίδων, βουλήσεως ἁ., Hdt. 1.207, E. Med. 498, Th. 1.33, 92; ἁ. τοῦ χρησμοῦ mistake it, Hdt. 1.71: c. acc., ἁ. τὸ ἀληθές Hdt. 7.139 (codd., τἀληθέος Schäfer).

fail of having, be deprived of, mostly c. gen., χειρῶν ἐξ Ὀδυσῆος ἁμαρτήσεσθαι ὀπωπῆς that I should lose my sight by Ulysses’ hands, Od. 9.512; τοῦ ῥυσίου θʼ ἥμαρτε A. Ag. 535; ἁ. πιστῆς ἀλόχου E. Alc. 879, cf. 144:—once with neut. Adj., οὐ γὰρ εἰκὸς . . ἐμὲ ὑμῶν ἁμαρτεῖν τοῦτό γʼ ʼtis not seemly that I should ask this of you in vain, S. Ph. 231:—rare in Prose, ἡμάρτομεν τῆς Βοιωτίης Hdt. 9.7.βʹ, cf. Th. 7.50; δυοῖν κακοῖν οὐκ ἦν ἁμαρτεῖν (i.e. either one or the other) And. 1.20, cf. S. El. 1320:—so μηδὲ δυοῖν φθάσαι ἁμάρτωσιν, ἢ . . ἢ . . fail to be before-hand in one of two things, Th. 1.33.
fail to do, neglect, φίλων ἡμάρτανε δώρων Il. 24.68; ξυμμαχίας ἁμαρτών A. Ag. 213.

children.label: II
children.definition: do wrong, err, sin, Il. 9.501, Semon. 7.111, A. Pr. 262, S. El. 1207, etc.; ἄκοντες ἡμαρτάνομεν Pl. R. 336e, cf. 340e, etc.:—c. part., ἥμαρτε χρηστὰ μωμένη S. Tr. 1136; πρόθυμος ὢν ἥμαρτες E. Or. 1630, cf. Antipho 2.2.1: c. dat. rei, ἁ. ῥήματι Pl. Grg. 489b; ἐν λόγοις Id. R. 396a; τοιαῦθʼ ἁμαρτάνουσιν ἐν λόγοις ἔπη S. Aj. 1096:—with cognate acc., ἁμαρτίαν ἁ. S. Ph. 1249, E. Hipp. 320: with neut. Adj. or Pron., αὐτὸς ἐγὼ τόδε γʼ ἤμβροτον I erred in this, Od. 22.154; πόλλʼ ἁμαρτών A. Supp. 915; ἀνθρώπινα X. Cyr. 3.1.40: in Prose more freq. ἁ. περί τινος or τι do wrong in a matter, Pl. Lg. 891e, Phdr. 242e; ἐπί τινι Antipho 5.91 (codd.); ἁ. εἴς τινα sin against . . , Hdt. 1.138, S. OC 968; ἐπὶ τὴν ἔλλειψιν, ἐπὶ τὸ πλεῖον, Arist. EN 1126b1, 1118b16; περί τινα Antipho 3.2.7; τινί LXX Jd. 10.10.

Pass., ἡμαρτήθη ὁ ἐς Σικελίαν πλοῦς Th. 2.65, etc.: in pf. part., τἀμὰ δʼ ἡμαρτημένα my plans are frustrate, S. OT 621; τῶν περὶ τὰ τοιαῦτα ἐς τὰ θεῖα ἁμαρτανομένων Pl. Lg. 759c; ἀπειρίᾳ αὐτὸ μᾶλλον ἢ ἀδικίᾳ ἡμαρτῆσθαι Antipho 5.5:— τὰ ἡμαρτημένα, τὰ ἁμαρτηθέντα, S. OC 439, 1269, X. An. 5.8.20.

data.quote: τῶν περὶ τὰ τοιαῦτα ἐς τὰ θεῖα ἁμαρτανομένων
ἀπειρίᾳ αὐτὸ μᾶλλον ἢ ἀδικίᾳ ἡμαρτῆσθαι

children.definition: ἁμαρτανόμενος, as Adj., wrong, mistaken, Pl. Phlb. 37d, al.; αἱ ἡμαρτημέναι πολιτεῖαι Id. R. 449a, Arist. Pol. 1275b1, 1301a36; and of persons, ἡμαρτημένοι mistaken, Id. EN 1125a19.

definition: ἁμαρτάς, άδος, ἡ, Ion. and later Gk. for ἁμαρτία, Hdt. 1.91, 119, al., Hp. Acut. 39, A. Fr. 451C, S. Fr. 999, Phld. Sto. 339.15, Eus.Mynd. Fr. 31, Olymp. in Mete. 146.7; copyistʼs

children.definition: error, Str. 13.1.54; sin, in religious sense, J. AJ 3.9.3, al.
attend, accompany, c. dat., B. 17.46, E. Fr. 682, prob. l. in Herod. 4.95.
together, at same time, at once, Il. 5.656, Od. 22.81, Sol. 33.4.

definition: ἁμαρτήδην, Adv. = ἁμαρτῆ, Sch. Il. 21.162, Hsch.

children.definition: failure, fault, S. Ant. 1261 (lyr.); freq. in Att. Prose, Antipho 3.3.8, Th. 2.65, etc.; midway between ἀδίκημα and ἀτύχημα, Arist. EN 1135b18, Rh. 1374b7; sinful action, opp. κατόρθωμα, Zeno Stoic. 1.54, cf. PTeb. 5.3, etc.; τὸ περὶ τὴν τέχνην λεγόμενον ἁ. Pl. Plt. 296b, cf. Ap. 22d; εἴς τινα Id. Lg. 729e; περὶ τὸ σῶμα Id. Grg. 479a.

data.quote: τὸ περὶ τὴν τέχνην λεγόμενον ἁ.

children.definition: sinful), Pl. (Com.?) ap. Phot. p. 88 R.
prone to err, Arist. EN 1104b33; περὶ τοὺς πλησίον M.Ant. 11.18.
a failure, fault, τῶνδʼ ἁ. δόμων A. Ag. 1197, etc.; οὐ τῇ ἑαυτοῦ ἁμαρτίᾳ χρῆσθαι Antipho 4.3.4; ἁ. δόξης error of judgement, Th. 1.32.
guilt, sin, Pl. Lg. 660c, al., Arist. EN 1148a3, al., LXX Ge. 18.20, al., Ev.Jo. 8.46, al.
failing of marriage, Nonn. D. 48.94.
erring in mind, distraught, Hes. Th. 511, Sol. 22.2, A. Supp. 542 (lyr.), Rhian. 1.1.
erring in words, speaking at random, Il. 13.824; οἶνος ἁ. wine that makes men talk at random, Poet. ap. Clem.Al. Paed. 2.2.28.
speaking faultily, Ath. 4.165b.
needing no witness, E. HF 290, Antiph. 311. Adv. ἀμαρτυρη-τί without witnesses, POxy. 1852.10 (vi A. D.).

without witness, unattested, Th. 2.41, D. 20.149, PFlor. 59.13 (iii A. D.); ἀμαρτύρων εὔντων Herod. 2.85; ἀ. οὐδὲν ἀείδω Call. Fr. 442; unsupported by evidence, δίκη Procop. Arc. 16, etc. Adv. -ρως Antipho Soph. 93b, D. 30.21, cf. Sch. Il. Oxy. 21.203.

definition: ἄμαρτυς, υ, = foreg., Agatho ap. Phot. p.87R.

children.definition: Thgn. 327, Rhian. 1.12; ἁ. διαίτης Aret. CD 1.6.

definition: ἁμαρτωλία, ἡ, = foreg., Hp. Epid. 2.1.8, Eup. 199, Ar. Pax 415.

children.definition: erroneous, ἁμαρτωλότερον Arist. EN 1109a33; erring, ἐν πᾶσιν Plu. Aud.poet. 2.25c.
of bad character, δοῦλοι Phld. Ir. p.73 W.: c. gen., sinning against, θεῶν Michel 547.31 ( Telmessus):— ἁμαρτωλὴ γέρων, barbarism in Ar. Th. 1111. Adv. -ῶς Eup. 24D.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. ἁμαρτωλός, ὁ, sinner, LXX Ge. 13.13, al., Ev.Luc. 18.13, al.

definition: ἀμαρυγή [ Att. ῠ, Ep. ῡ], ἡ,

children.definition: sparkling, twinkling, glancing, of objects in motion, as of the eye, h.Merc. 45; of stars, A.R. 2.42; of the sun, Procop. Vand. 2.14; of any quick motion, ἵππων ἀ. Ar. Av. 925:— also ἀμάρυγξ, γγος, ἡ, Hdn.Gr. 2.743: ἀμάρυξις, εως, ἡ, Sch. A.R. 3.1018.

sparkle, twinkle, ἀ. λάμπρον προσώπω flashing, radiant glance, Sapph. Supp. 5.18, cf. A.R. 3.288; of changing colour, and light, AP 5.258 ( Paul.Sil.); διδύμης ἀ. χροιῆς, of gems, Tryph. 71, etc.; of any quick, light motion, Χαρίτων ἀμαρύγματʼ ἔχουσα with the flashing steps of Graces, Hes.
